DOC.HEAD: Agitated President Bush Says Iraqi Aggression `Will Not Stand'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 7-9, ``The Washington xxx with report of destablization planning
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday that Iraq ``lied once again'' and reneged on its pledge to pull its invading forces out of Kuwait. Angry and forceful, the president again condemned Iraq's aggression and said, ``This will not stand.'' Bush dispatched Secretary Dick Cheney to Saudi Arabia to confer with leaders of the desert kingdom, administration sources said. Bush conferred Sunday evening for 1{ hours at the White House with his top civilian and military advisers, including Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``They reviewed the situation in the Gulf,'' said White House spokesman Doug Davidson. He would not elaborate. Bush turned aside reporters' questions about whether Turkey or Saudi Arabia would shut off pipelines critical to Iraq's oil distribution, and he refused to discuss any military action the United States might be planning. ``I'm not going to discuss what we're doing in terms of moving of forces, anything of that nature,'' he said. The Washington Post reported in its Monday editions that the U.S. contingency planning includes planning to destabilize and eventually topple Saddam from power. The account, attributed to unidentified sources, said it could not be learned what timetable Bush has set for making decisions about how to implement such a campaign. ``We don't comment on options or intelligence matters,'' said Davidson in response to the account. Bush said he would meet Monday at the White House with NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, on her way home from Aspen, Colo. Speaking on condition of anonymity, an administration source said it hadn't been determined whether Cheney will visit only Ryadh, the Saudi capital, or other Mideast nations as well. Bush praised Japan's decision to join an international boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, and said he planned to speak again with Turkish President Turgut Ozal as part of the ``intensive diplomatic activity around the world.'' He said he had offered Kuwait's emir, now in exile, ``certain assurances'' in a telephone conversation on Saturday. Bush said his goal is to isolate Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. The United States swiftly imposed an economic boycott on Iraq after its lightning invasion of Kuwait last Wednesday, and Bush has spent much of his time since then urging other nations to join in pressuring Baghdad economically. ``These are outlaws, international outlaws and renegades,'' he said of the Iraqi leadership. ``There seems to be a united front out there that says Iraq, having committed brutal, naked aggression, ought to get out and this concept of their installing some puppet leaving behind will not (be) acceptable,'' the president said. Bush was clearly agitated, cutting short reporters' questions at times and speaking in terse sentences. He ended the impromptu news conference with these words: ``This will not stand,'' he said. ``This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait.'' Bush said he considered his options ``wide open.'' He was asked whether Turkey and Saudi Arabia would shut off the oil pipelines that provide a critical outlet for Iraqi's oil. ``There is a strong feeling on the part of the NATO countries to whom I've talked, Turkey being one of them, that we must have concerted action to isolate Iraq economically and you can just assume from there that those matters are being considered,'' he said. Bush said the Iraqis had not pulled back their invading forces, as they promised Friday they would. The Iraqis ``lied once again. They said they were going to start moving out today and there is no evidence they're moving out,'' he said. ``I want to see the Arab states join the rest of the world in condemning this outrage and doing what they can to get Saddam Hussein out,'' said Bush. Asked about Jordan King Hussein's defense of the Iraqi ruler, Bush said, ``I am disappointed to find any comment by anyone that apologizes or appears to condone what's taken place.'' Jordan's monarch said Saturday that other Arab states were ``premature'' in condemning the Iraqi invasion. He called Iraq's ruler ``a patriotic man who believes in his nation and its future and in establishing ties with others on the basis of mutual respect.'' Arab leaders have warned against foreign intervention, but an emergency Arab League summit to discuss the crisis initially planned for Sunday in Saudi Arabia was postponed. Bush said an Arab leader ``that I respect enormously' told him Friday ``they needed 48 hours to find what they called an Arab solution. That obviously has failed. ... Of course I'm disappointed.'' Jordan's prime minister, Mudar Badran, said his natin will not recognize the new government because that would hinder Arab efforts to end the conflict. Asked how he would prevent the Iraqis from installing its new government, Bush snapped, ``Just wait. Watch and learn.'' He also said the Iraqi-installed government in Kuwait would gain little recognition internationally. ``There is no intention on the part of any of these countries to accept a puppet government. And that signal is going out loud and clear to Iraq,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Outbound Traffic Moves from Poert for 1st Time Since Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with two-way port traffic reopened, number of ships moving; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `At a ...'; DELETES redundant or outdated grafs 13-14 bgng `The ship ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT5
DOC.TEXT: Contractors sprayed oil-eating bacteria on marshes Sunday while crews vacuumed up heavy sludge that drifted northward from a spill of up to 700,000 gallons of oil. Ships were allowed to leave the harbor for the first time in more than a week. Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said wind pushed a slick of oil surrounding Houston Point and its sensitive marshes back into Galveston Bay on Sunday. Some of the oil washed ashore, while streamers of up to 100 yards in length moved northeast toward Trinity Bay, a marine area. Approximately 315,000 gallons of the refinery oil from the barge-tanker collision had been collected by Sunday afternoon, Greene said. About 150 contract workers and 90 Coast Guardsmen were working on the cleanup, which will cost about $5 million, Greene said. The oil was spilled July 28 when the Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two barges under tow by the Chandy N in the Houston Ship Channel. ``Traffic is moving, just not freely,'' said Scott Inbody, chief warrant officer of the Coast Guard's vessel traffic service in Houston. ``We're making sure no vessels meet or overtake each other in the waters near the accident.'' The ship channel was opened to inbound towboat traffic Friday. It had been closed since the accident while the Coast Guard worked to free the barge that had partially sunk in the collision. The Coast Guard hoped to open the channel to unrestricted two-way traffic by Monday, Inbody said. ``We have outbound ships and inbound towboats, pulling or pushing barges, moving right now,'' he said. About 40 vessels were waiting to get into the channel and 10 were waiting to leave late Sunday, the Coast Guard said. At a hearing on collision Sunday, Shinoussa crewmen blamed the Houston pilot who guided them through the channel for bad directions. The pilot contends the helmsman failed to follow instructions and steered into the oncoming barges after another ship passed. State officials planned to spread about 150 pounds of the bacteria around Houston Point and its marshes Sunday. The microbes, which occur naturally in small amounts, are bred to reduce oil to a fatty substance that sinks and can be eaten by fish. When the oil is gone, the microbes die. The process is called bioremediation. ``We've got oil about 30 feet into the marshlands,'' Texas Water Commission chairman B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne said Sunday. ``We're trying to do as much as we can today.'' Wynne said bacteria used on Pelican Island last week seems to have been beneficial, but tests have not been completed. ``This is different from oil on rocks or oil in open waters,'' Wynne said. ``This is on a living, organic system and it's absolutely the most sensitive place it can be.'' Dead crabs, mussels and other small marine animals have been found on the shore around Houston Point, said Larry McKinney, director of the resource protection division of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. A ban on shrimping in Galveston Bay continued Sunday, but fin fishing remained open.

DOC.HEAD: Liberians Hope U.S. Marines Will Land and End Civil War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 4th `The Marines...' to UPDATE with 74 sted 59 people lifted out; pickup graf 5 `The United...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Liberians have long hoped that the hundreds of U.S. Marines who swooped into Monrovia on Sunday to rescue Americans and shore up Embassy defenses would also help end their civil war. Besieged President Samuel Doe, Liberia's Council of Churches and rebel leader Prince Johnson all have called on the United States to use force to help end the conflict. A total of 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed. Johnson's threat Saturday to start detaining foreigners in the hope of provoking foreign intervention brought the order to dispatch the Marines to Monrovia. The Marines returned to their ships with 62 Americans and 12 people from other countries, leaving behind a group of soldiers to shore up Embassy defenses. The United States has insisted it will not intervene to end the 7-month-long war, but many Liberians have hoped for more. When the warships carrying the Marines first arrived off the Liberian coast two months ago, people danced in the streets of the capital singing of how the soldiers would save them. But the Marines remained offshore and last week Johnson asked reporters, ``Why does the United States not come to the aid of Liberia, which looks on America as its motherland?'' His puzzlement is shared by many people in this West African nation that was founded by freed American slaves in 1847. Johnson said he appealed last week to the U.S. Embassy for American help to stop the killing of civilians but was told that the crisis was an ``internal conflict.'' ``As though the United States had never interfered in the affairs of other people like those of Grenada, the Philippines or Panama?'' Johnson argued. Appeals for U.S. intervention mounted after early hopes that the men of rival rebel leader Charles Taylor would quickly take Monrovia were dashed. Doe remains inside his presidential mansion, protected by loyalist troops, while Johnson and Taylor's forces, once united, have clashed with each other as the siege of Monrovia continues. In June, thousands of peace marchers led by Christian and Moslem leaders ignored death threats from Doe and demanded U.S. intervention. ``We are appealing to the Congress, to the government and to the people of the United States of America to come to our aid. This is an SOS call. Save our souls,'' appealed one of the leaders, Bishop W. Nah Dixon, when marchers stopped outside the U.S. Embassy. Hundreds of the protesters, waving banners reading ``Stop the Killings,'' came from a refugee center set up at St. Peter's Lutheran Church. On July 30, Doe's soldiers massacred more than 600 people who sought refuge at that church. Many Liberians blame the United States in part for the present conflict, pointing to the $500 million Washington pumped into the country to support Doe after he seized power in a bloody 1980 coup. U.S. aid continued to pour in, despite reports that Doe rigged the 1985 elections and allegations of massive government corruption. Lethal military aid was suspended in 1986 after Doe's soldiers massacred more than 2,000 civilians to put down a rebellion. But U.S. military advisers remained until last month, when Doe accused them of supporting the rebels and ordered them out of the country. Many of Taylor's soldiers joined the rebellion to avenge family members killed by Doe's soldiers. The rebellion began in December when Taylor's forces invaded from Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption and human rights abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Rescued From Brink of Falls
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A woman jumped into the Niagara River in an apparent suicide attempt Sunday, but changed her mind after landing in rapids and was rescued 75 yards from the brink of Niagara Falls, police said. Alice Goldman, 38, of Thorn Hill, Ontario, jumped into the river from a bridge leading to Goat Island above the American Falls, said Sgt. Donald Compton of the New York State Parks Police. Once in the water, the woman tried unsuccessfully tried to swim to shore and clung to rocks, he said. After rescuers determined they couldn't reach her from land, parks police called a tourist helicopter service, and a chopper lifted her to safety, Compton said. She was admitted to Niagara Falls Memorial Hospital for a psychiatric evaluation.

Japan Sets New Longevity Records
DOC.TEXT: Japan extended its own world record for longevity in 1989, with average life expectancy for women increasing 0.38 years to 81.77 and men 0.30 years to 75.91, the Ministry of Health and Welfare reported. Since 1986, Japan has led the world in life expectancy for both men and women. When the ministry compiled its first longevity statistics in 1947, the average life expectancy for women was 53.96 and for men 50.06. The ministry, in its weekend report, also predicted that 24 percent of women born last year will die of heart attacks while 10 percent are expected to die of strokes and 17 percent from cancer. The leading causes of death for men born last year are likely to be cancer at 26 percent, heart attacks at 20 percent and strokes at 15 percent, it said. Japan is one of the most rapidly aging nations in the world in terms of the average age of its population. The ministry predicted that 23.6 percent of the Japanese people will be 65 or older in the year 2020.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Resigns Over Same Woman Who Caused Archbishop's Departure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The Rev. ...' to change attribution to bishop from spokesman; INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `It wasn't known ...' to UPDATE with Woods said to have used parish funds to help woman; edits 6th graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The Catholic archdiocese announced Saturday that a priest had resigned because of a relationship with the same woman whose ``intimate'' ties with Archbishop Eugene Marino forced him to step down last month. The woman, 27-year-old Vicki R. Long, sued the church for paternity payments stemming from her alleged relationship with a third priest. The church is paying child support but denies the priest is the father. The Rev. Michael Woods, pastor at St. Jude's Catholic Church in Sandy Springs, an Atlanta suburb, offered to resign Saturday after confessing to an intimate relationship with Ms. Long, a Riverdale lay minister, said Bishop James Lyke, acting administrator of the Atlanta Archdiocese. It wasn't known if the church had accepted Wood's resignation. The bishop said Woods used an undisclosed amount of parish funds to help Ms. Long. In a statement read to his congregation by an archdiocese spokesman, Woods said his relationship with Ms. Long has ended, but did not say how long when it had begun. Marino, who originally claimed health reasons for his departure last month, had a two-year relationship with Ms. Long, church officials said last week. Lyke has refused to say whether Marino's relationship with Ms. Long was sexual, calling it ``intimate.'' Marino, last known to be recuperating in New York, has not commented publicly. Ms. Long has charged that another priest, Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, Ga., fathered her daughter born in 1986. Blood tests concluded he was not the father. Experts say the resignation of Marino, the nation's highest-ranking black Catholic, will heighten debate over mandatory celibacy, a church law adopted in the Middle Ages partly to curb corruption and nepotism in the church. ``Celibacy is unrealistic and it's counterproductive now,'' said Richard McBrien, theology chairman at the University of Notre Dame. ``The priesthood as we've known it is falling apart ... because of a stubborn refusal to change.'' Pope John Paul II strongly supports the celibacy requirement. During his 1987 visit to the United States, he said a priest's love for Christ must be paramount and is ``at the foundation of our commitment to celibacy. This love also makes it possible for us, as servants of God's kingdom, to love our people freely and chastely and deeply.'' McBrien noted that there are increasingly fewer qualified priests in this country. About 15 percent of priests have left the order since 1970 and officials expect applications for seminary to decline 40 percent by the year 2000. The Rev. Terrence Dosh, national coordinator for Corpus, a support group for married ex-priests, said Marino's stature draws attention to a worldwide disregard for celibacy. ``In the past 25 years, 19,000 American Roman Catholic priests resigned and married and 110,000 in the world resigned and married. It takes the situation of a bishop to draw attention to it,'' he said. Dosh said scholars believe mandatory celibacy has its roots in the Old Testament call for ritual purity. Women were believed impure, so priests were forbidden to have sexual intercourse the night before celebrating eucharist. In 1139, mandatory celibacy was adopted. ``Celibacy is quintessentially anti-woman,'' he said. Cathy Grenier of Good Tidings, a Pennsylvania support group for women and priests, said celibacy is a feminist issue. ``The attitude toward women is that if a priest touches a woman he's tainted,'' said Mrs. Grenier, who married a priest. ``If women were not believed inherently evil and dirty, there'd be no problem with marrying us.'' McBrien said he believed mandatory celibacy would be stopped, but perhaps in a ``long and bloody'' manner. ``Ask a random sample of Catholics whether they are impressed with the fact that priests don't marry, if it makes them more of a spiritually credible person. Most would say no, just the opposite,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Evicts Striking Banana Workers From Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEDES with 11 grafs to CORRECT that 4,000 workers at installation at time of eviction, town occupied, more quotes from military. Pickup 7th graf `Labor Minister...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of army troops on Saturday evicted about 4,000 striking workers who occupied the U.S.-owned Chiquita banana packing plant for 41 days in a northern town. Clashes were reported. At least two workers were wounded by gunfire and two others were beaten when the army evicted workers from the installations in La Lima, 180 miles north of Tegucigalpa, said union spokesman Alejandro Maldonado. A military intelligence source said at least two workers and one unidentified person were wounded. The circumstances of the clashes were not immediately known. The 600 troops also occupied La Lima and the government announced that the Chiquita Brands, which produces and exports most of Honduras' banana crop, could hire new employees and resume production. Earlier Saturday, the company rejected a proposed 30 percent pay increase for the workers, who began their strike June 25. About 4,000 of the 10,000 striking workers had peacefully occupied Chiquita offices, workshops and packing and cleaning installations during the strike. The other 6,000 had remained behind closed gates in about 80 camps where they live around the installations. Troops did not enter the camps. ``La Lima has been occupied by the armed forces,'' the military source said. ``The situation in La Lima is tense, but there has been no armed response from the workers.'' He said troops had removed the strikers and remained in the main installations. On Sunday, he said, a military operation would begin ``in all the banana camps to definitely reestablish order in that sector.'' About 300 soldiers arrived in trucks and quickly occupied the installations. They were reinforced by 300 more soldiers and police, the source said. Labor Minister Rodolfo Rosales Abella, speaking on national radio and television, said President Rafael Leonardo Callejas and his Cabinet decided to end the strike. ``The government guarantees the right to work of all employees of the company, union members or not, who desire to renew their labor,'' Rosales said. ``The government also guarantees the right of Chiquita Brand to contract the necessary personnel for its normal operation,'' he said. The strike ``constituted a threat to the social and economic stability of the country,'' he said. Cincinnati-based Chiquita Brand produces and exports 60 percent of Honduras' bananas, the country's main export. Karl F. Koch, general manager of Chiquita Brand International in Honduras, told The Associated Press on Saturday that his company ``absolutely rejects the new salary demand of 30 percent for the workers.'' The strikers Friday rejected a July 28 proposal by the nation's president for a 25 percent raise, which would have been acceptable to the company. Instead, they demanded a raise of 30 percent. Earlier, they had asked for a 60 percent increase over the $246-a-month minimum salary. Groups representing 600,000 workers and peasants had threatened to launch a general strike Monday if the strike is not solved.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Diana Gains Strength in Caribbean
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES throughout with Diana gaining strength.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Diana steadily gained strength Saturday in the Caribbean Sea and was expected to buffet portions of Belize and the east coast of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Sunday, meteorologists said. Tropical storm warnings were likely in those areas, the National Weather Service said. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Cesar was crossing the mid-Atlantic with 50 mph winds and posing no threat to land. Late Saturday, Diana was centered near 17.1 north latitude and 84.2 west longitude, or 335 miles southeast of Cancun, Mexico. It was moving northwest at 14 mph, and that motion was expected to continue through Sunday, the weather service said. Maximum sustained winds were near 40 mph and expected to increase in strength Sunday, the weather service said. Tropical storm-force winds extended 80 miles from the center, it said. Cesar was centered late Saturday near 23.6 north latitude and 44.7 west longitude, or about 1,300 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde Islands off Africa. ``Cesar is really not of any concern to anybody,'' said Noel Risnychok at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``It's position is still way, way out in the Atlantic, and it's really of no threat or concern to anybody except for maybe some shipping.'' The storm was moving northwest at 8 mph with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquakes Hit Seabed Off Japan
DOC.TEXT: Three earthquakes struck the seabed far off Japan's eastern shore Sunday, but no injuries or damage were reported on the main islands, officials said. The Central Meteorological Agency reported that there was no danger of tsunami, or tidal waves, following the quakes which measured up to 6.6 on the Richter scale. Police in Tokyo and Ibaraki prefectures (states) said they had not received any immediate reports of damage or casualties. The strongest of the three temblors struck 220 miles beneath the ocean floor off Japan's Pacific coast at 10:36 a.m. (9:36 p.m. EDT Saturday). It measured 6.6 on the Richter scale at the epicenter. It was followed by two aftershocks at 12:25 p.m. (11:25 p.m. EDT Saturday) and 12:36 p.m. (11:36 p.m. EDT Saturday), the second of which was estimated at 5.8 on the Richter scale. There was no magnitude available for the first aftershock. The Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake at its epicenter according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 6 on the Richter scale is considered severe, capable of widespread damage near the epicenter.

DOC.HEAD: China Embargoes Arms Sales to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: China will not sell arms to Iraq, the official Xinhua news agency said Sunday, joining other nations cutting off trade with the Baghdad government after the invasion of Kuwait. Xinhua quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that since China supported the U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait it would ``naturally, not sell arms to Iraq under such circumstances.'' The brief report did not elaborate on the ministry official's comment, which it said was in response to a reporter's question on whether China would embargo arms sales to Iraq after Thursday's invasion. In the past, China has officially denied selling arms to Iraq, but Western intelligence reports indicate Beijing has supplied billions of dollars worth of arms, including anti-ship Silkworm missiles, to Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in N.D. Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A light aircraft slammed into a hillside shortly after taking off from a rural road Saturday night, killing a 32-year-old man and his 10-year-old niece, police said. The two-seat, single-engine Cessna took off shortly before 8 p.m., flew over a gulch and crashed into a hillside about 4 miles north of Donnybrook, said Highway Patrol Officer Gary Burgett. The pilot, from Moreno Valley, Calif., had rented the plane in Minot, 25 miles away, and picked up his niece on a rural road. Their identities were not immediately released. ``As to what happened, I don't know,'' Burgett said. ``We have to wait for the people to get up there and make a determination. There was still fuel in the plane, so I don't know.'' Witnesses saw the plane turning before disappearing behind the hill, Burgett said. The pilot passed a California flying test in July, the patrolman said. ``He was qualified to fly a plane and he was qualified to fly that type of a plane,'' Burgett said. Federal Aviation Administration officials were expected to visit the crash site Sunday, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Santa Cruz Mountains
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the Santa Cruz Mountains on Saturday night, but no injuries were reported. The U.S. Geological Survey reported the 11:52 p.m. temblor measured 4.3 on the Richter scale and was centered near the town of San Juan Bautista, about 75 miles southeast of San Francisco. ``It was just enough to rattle things and make the pots swing. But it seemed very small,'' said Linda Parker, a clerk with the Salinas police department. The temblor served as another reminder for Northern California residents of the deadly Oct. 17, 1989, earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area that measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people and caused billions of dollars in damage. Quakes of magnitude 4 to 5 are considered moderate and could cause some minor damage such as broken china and cracks in poorly built structures.

DOC.HEAD: Fire In Apartment Building Kills Five
DOC.TEXT: A fire roared through a four-story apartment building where half the residents are elderly, killing five people, police said Sunday. Deputy Fire Chief Steve Spink said three people who escaped the fire Saturday evening suffered minor injuries. Two firefighters were treated for shoulder injuries, he said. The building housed 20 residents. ``A number of residents had exited, some had jumped and were injured on the pavement, and a number had to be rescued via ladder,'' Spink said. The cause of the fire was not known, Spink said. The identities of the victims were not immediately released, pending notification of their families. Most of the building's tenants lived in small apartments or single rooms, said Ulrich Fellenher, who identified himself as the building's landlord. About 50 firefighters fought the blaze. Some residents jumped from upper-floor windows onto the roof of a building next door, Spink said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: through Carle.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. action came hours after rebel leader Prince Johnson said in Liberia that he was ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia in hope of provoking international intervention in the nation's bloody civil war. Johnson, whose troops have occupied much of the city in their battle to oust President Samuel Doe, told reporters the roundup would begin Monday and single out American, British, Lebanese and Indian civilians at first. Four U.S. warships containing 4,000 Marines had been stationed off the Liberian coast for weeks, but Washington previously had has ruled out intervening.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Military Camps Placed on Red Alert with Coup Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Officials placed most military camps on full alert Sunday after raw intelligence reports said dissident soldiers would try to launch another coup bid to topple President Corazon Aquino, a military spokesman said. ``Unconfirmed reports about another coup attempt by rebel elements prompted the Philippine Constabulary to raise alert status,'' military spokesman Lt. Col. Cresencio Maralit told reporters. Brig. Gen. Lisandro Abadia, operations chief of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, said that the red alert status was ordered in the army, air force and constabulary headquarters in Manila. A red alert status means that soldiers are ordered to barracks. Maralit did not give details on the reported coup attempt, nor its duration. Mrs. Aquino has survived at least six coup attepts during her four-year term. On Dec. 1, mutineers belonging to the Reform the Armed Forces Movement, launched a nine-day coup try that killed 113 people and wounded about 600 people. Since last year's failed coup, renegades have been threatening to strike, but a devastating earthquake that rocked Luzon island last month prompted dissidents to offer a cease-fire to help rebuild the nation. Mrs. Aquino rejected the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Diana May Strengthen; Warnings Posted in Mexico, Belize
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm warnings were posted early Sunday for the Caribbean coastlines of Mexico and Belize as forecasters predicted Tropical Storm Diana could strengthen. The storm warnings extended from Cancun, Mexico, to Belize City, including offshore islands, according to a statement by the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Up to 5 inches of rain is possible in sections of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. Heavy rainfall was also possible along the north coast of Honduras, the center reported. Forecasters predicted Diana could intensify Sunday as it moves through the western Caribbean. Maximum sustained winds early Sunday were near 45 mph. At 6 a.m. EDT, Diana was centered near 17.7 north latitude and 85.4 west longitude, or 250 miles south southeast of Cancun. It was moving northwest at 14 mph, and that motion was expected to continue through Monday. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Cesar was crossing the mid-Atlantic with 50 mph winds and posing no threat to land. Cesar was centered at 6 a.m. EDT near 24.2 north latitude and 46.7 west longitude, or about 1,250 miles east southeast of Bermuda. ``Cesar is really not of any concern to anybody ... except for maybe some shipping,'' Noel Risnychok of the hurricane center said Saturday. The storm was moving northwest at 12 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Being Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEAD with 4 grafs to UPDATE with White House comments on evacuation; pick up 4th graf, bgng ``Some 225 ...; EDITS to tighten. ^By SUSANNE M. SCHAFER
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines rescued 59 Americans from the U.S. Embassy compound in Liberia Sunday without ``any shots being fired or resistance encountered,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Two hours after the operation was announced, Pentagon sources reported the U.S. citizens were safe aboard the USS Saipan, a helicopter assault ship off the shore of the Liberian capital of Monrovia. ``We've been advised that the initial stages of this morning's Liberia operation have been successfully completed,'' said Fitzwater. ``A total of 59 people were flown to U.S. Navy ships offshore by U.S. Marine Corp helicopters. ``The U.S. Marine Corp Reinforced Rifle Co. is in place providing protection for U.S. citizens. The initial operation went well and we are unaware of any shots being fired or resistance encountered.'' Some 225 Marines were involved in the airborne operation, which made use of 17 aircraft, including light attack jets, assault helicopters and transport choppers, to fly the Americans to safety, the sources said. President Bush ordered the evacuation after one of the rebel leaders trying to oust President Samuel Doe announced he was ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia in hope of provoking international intervention in the nation's bloody civil war, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said about 70 U.S. officials and 300 other Americans were in Liberia and that ``we'll take out as many as want to get out.'' The Marine presence ``does not indicate or constitute any intention on the part of the U.S. government to intervene militarily in the Liberian conflict,'' the spokesman said. The Marines will evacuate the Americans who wish to leave, draw down the number of U.S. officials at the Embassy and shore up the embassy's defenses to guard the skeleton staff that will remain behind, Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor called for civilians and fighters to mobilize. In a broadcast from a radio station in northern Yekepa town, Taylor asked all Liberians ``to defend your country'' and ``oppose all foreign intervention.'' U.S. officials had begun notifying Americans on that the evacuation could take place, and military officials expect that many of the 300 Americans will decline to take part, the officials said. ``It's up to them, whether they want to go, but it seems that many of them want to remain,'' one official said. The Americans were expected to be transported by air to Freetown, Sierra Leone, the nation on Liberia's northern border. Some of the Marine riflemen were also dispatched to two transmitter sites for diplomatic communications to secure the safety of Americans workings there. Later, the Pentagon sources reported that the Americans located at both sites had been evacuated. ``We are essentially abandoning the sites,'' the source said of the transmitters located there. A spokesman for Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., chairman of the African affairs subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the senator was informed of the operation by the State Department at 5:20 a.m. EDT. ``The president's action is a proper one, and I support his decision,'' the senator, who was in Chicago, said in a statement issued through spokesman David Carle. ``It sounds like a sensible operation and an appropiate response,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., who also was notified in advance. Cranston is chairman of the Foreign Relations subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs and a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee. Fitzwater noted that the United States had maintained ships off the Liberian shore for several weeks, but had not taken sides in the fighting. The U.S. ships involved in the operation include the amphibious assault helicopter carrier USS Saipan; the USS Ponce, an amphibious transport dock ship; the USS Sumter, a tank landing ship; and the destroyer USS Peterson. About 2,200 Marines, based at Camp LeJeune, N.C., are aboard the ships. Pentagon sources said one radio transmitter site is about 20 kilometers southeast of Monrovia and the other 20 kilometers northeast of the city. The Marines were expected to gather the Americans inside the embassy compound, where they could be properly identified and processed for transport by helicopter to the ships waiting off shore, the sources said. The Marine amphibious readiness unit on the Saipan made use of nine CH-46 ``Sea Knight'' helicopters to transport the Marines and the Americans, and two CH-53 ``Sea Stallion'' choppers to carry cargo, weapons and transport vehicles, the Pentagon sources said. Four AH-1 ``Sea Cobra'' attack choppers flew to the transmitter sites to secure the Americans there and security for the air resuce operation was provided by AV-8B Harrier light attack jets, the sources said. ``They will be shuttling back and forth until it's done,'' the official said. Fitzwater said U.S. forces were sent in ``to immediately secure the embassy, accomplish the rescue operation, secure and remove Americans from two communications sites (and) remain as long as necessary to assure the security'' of remaining embassy staff. The spokesman announced the deployment in an early morning briefing at the White House as Bush monitored developments from the presidential retreat at Camp David. ``The Marines will remain in Liberia as long as necessary to insure the safety of U.S. citizens in that country,'' Fitzwater said. He said the embassy would remain open with a skeleton staff. ``The Marines are there to protect lives. They are authorized whatever means are necessary to do that. And they are there in a battle situation. And we have notified the Congress to that effect.'' Prince Johnson, whose rebel troops have occupied much of the city in their battle to oust Doe, told reporters Saturday his roundup of foreigners would begin Monday and single out American, British, Lebanese and Indian civilians at first. The U.S. transmitters were in territory held by Charles Taylor, a rival rebel leader who has threatened repeatedly to attack any foreign troops. The first word of a foreigner killed in the conflict had come Saturday with a report that a Lebanese native who had lived in the Liberian capital for more than 15 years was shot to death in front of his wife and four children. The fighting in the civil war is centered in Monrovia, where forces loyal to Johnson are trying to topple Doe, whose troops were defending Doe's fortified mansion. Forces loyal to Taylor had been stopped by Doe's troops east of the capital. At least 2,000 foreigners, mostly Lebanese and Indian traders, still live in the embattled capital. Besides the Americans, the Westerners include a few dozen Britons.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi-Installed Kuwaiti Government Says Withdrawal Under Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE comment on formerly missing Americans, reporters in Iraq brought to see returning Iraqi soldiers, Jordan refusing to back new Kuwaiti government, denial that new government contains Iraqis. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The radio of Kuwait's new Iraqi-installed government claimed that Iraqi troops began pulling out of Kuwait on Sunday, but the United States said it doubted a withdrawal was really under way. The radio announcement came three days after Iraq invaded Kuwait and one day after Baghdad said it had replaced the oil-rich kingdom's ousted monarchy with a new government made up of nine Kuwaiti army offices. Iraq also said Saturday that it was creating a new Kuwaiti army and that 100,000 Iraqis, the approximate number of soldiers Baghdad took over Kuwait with, had volunteered for the new military force. In other developments: _The White House continued to seek the immediate and unconditional withdrawl of all Iraqi troops, and it thanked the many nations who have condemned the invasion and imposed economic sanctions on Baghdad. _After several days of debate, Japan on Sunday banned all oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and halted Japanese exports to both countries. Tokyo said it would suspend all loans to Iraq and Kuwait, ban Japanese investment there, and freeze Iraqi assets in Japan. Japan, which imports 99 percent of its oil, had relied on Iraq and Kuwait for more than 11 percent of its oil imports. The White House hailed Japan's move and said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu called President Bush on Sunday at Camp David to inform him about the sanctions. _Although tens of thousands of Iraqi troops reportedly remained massed near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia, Washington said on Sunday there was no indication that any soldiers had moved into Saudi Arabia. _The White House said that 11 American oil workers rounded up after the invasion had been brought to Baghdad, talked with U.S. Embassy officials, and were in good shape. It said that accounts for all missing Americans. _An unconfirmed report said a warplane from the deposed emir's air force in Kuwait bombed an Iraqi military headquarters near Kuwait city. It was not clear where the plane came from or whether its reported attack caused any damage. The radio of Kuwait's new government, monitored in Bahrain, quoted its ``military correspondent'' as saying the pullout began at 8 a.m. (1 a.m. EDT). Iraqi President Saddam Hussein allowed reporters based in Baghdad to be taken south to Basra overnight to observe the first Iraqi troops return home. But at the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said on Sunday morning: ``We have no independent or confirmable information on this report (of the withdrawl beginning). Saddam Hussein's actions in the past have raised serious skepticism about his intentions.'' Iraq declared earlier that the provisional government installed by Baghdad is capable of ensuring security in the occupied country. Baghdad television has said the new government is headed by Col. Ala Hussein Ali and that he holds the positions of prime minister, commander-in-chief of the armed forces, minister of defense and interior minister. The other eight members were lieutenant colonels and majors. But Kuwait's embassy in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday dismissed the new government as ``a list of fake names'' and said Ali is Saddam's son-in-law. A similar report appeared in one of Cairo's leading newspapers, Al-Ahram. It quoted the Kuwait Embassy in Tunis which said that Ali works with Saddam's administration in Baghdad. The Iraqi news agency carried a Kuwait-datelined statement it said was from the provisional government, denying any of its members were Iraqis. In Jordan, Prime Minister Mudar Badran said his nation will not recognize the new government because that would hinder Arab efforts to end the conflict. U.S., French and British warships, meanwhile, steamed toward the Persian Gulf. President Bush said Friday that if Iraq moved against Saudi Arabia it would be attacking U.S. ``vital interests.'' On Saturday, Bush said in Washington that the use of force in resolving the crisis remains an option. Saudi Arabia ships 1.2 million barrels of oil to the United States daily. Fitzwater said on Sunday that there was no indication Iraqi forces had moved into Saudi Arabia, even though tens of thousands of them have been reported to be within 5 to 10 miles of the Saudi border. In Washington, Iraqi ambassador Mohammed al-Mashat on Saturday denied U.S. and other foreign reports suggesting that Iraq plans to invade Saudi Arabia. Saddam ordered the invasion of Kuwait after accusing it of stealing oil from a field that straddles their disputed border. He also blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil prices that cost Iraq $14 billion, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on its OPEC oil cartel production quotas.

DOC.HEAD: White House Seriously Skeptical of Iraqi Withdrawal Claim
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS graf 9 pvs, bgng ``He declined ..., to delete reference to recognition of provisional government. Fitzwater was referring to other matters. ^By TERENCE HUNT
DOC.TEXT: The White House expressed ``serious skepticism'' Sunday over claims that Iraq was pulling its invading forces out of Kuwait. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater also said there was no indication that Iraqi forces had moved into Saudi Arabia, even though they were within 5 to 10 miles of the Saudi border. President Bush, spending the weekend at Camp David, consulted by telephone with Saudi King Fahd, Turkish President Turgut Ozal, the emir of Kuwait and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on Saturday. ``The United States continues to seek the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and restoration of a legitimate government of that country,'' Fitzwater said. ``We continue to consider all options in accordance with that policy.'' The radio of the Iraqi-backed Kuwaiti government said Iraqi troops began pulling out of the oil-rich country Sunday, three days after they were ordered to invade by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. At the White House, Fitzwater said, ``We have no independent or confirmable information on this report. ``Saddam Hussein's actions in the past have raised serious skepticism about his intentions,'' the White House spokesman said. He declined comment on reports that Jordan's King Hussein had defended Iraq's president. ``We're in the process of trying to work out a solution here and it does no good, serves no useful purpose, to try to characterize individual actions,'' Fitzwater said. As to a report in The Washington Post that special operations forces and hostage rescue forces have already been dispatched to the Mideast and that contingency plans call for sending Stealth fighters and B-52 bombers, Fitzwater said, ``I can't comment on any specific military actions or movements.'' Reporting on the status of missing U.S. citizens, Fitzwater confirmed that 11 American oil workers rounded up after the invasion had been brought to Baghdad. He said they had talked with U.S. embassy officials. ``They appear to be in good shape and this accounts for all missing Americans,'' Fitzwater said. ``They are safe and pursuing courses of their own free will.'' One possible avenue of applying pressure against Iraq would be to close down the pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia through which most of Iraqi's oil flows. ``Clearly they are part of the equation,'' Fitzwater said. When asked if Ozal or Fahd had made a commitment to close the pipelines, Fitzwater said, ``We can't comment on specific actions or agreements that have been reached in terms of private conversations.'' He added, ``I'm not prepared to comment on any conclusions that they may have reached at this time.'' Fitzwater said the pipelines apparently are still open. Fitzwater discussed developments in the Middle East at an early-morning White House briefing where he announced that 225 Marines had been sent into Liberia to evacuate Americans and protect the U.S. Embassy there from the country's civil war. Asked if the U.S. action in Liberia carried a message to Saddam, Fitzwater said, ``I wouldn't link the two. ... There really is no relationship between these actions in two separate parts of the world. ``It does, of course, point up, that President Bush is extremely concerned about the welfare of American citizens,'' Fitzwater said. ``We have acted time and again on behalf of their safety. ... I'm sure that Iraq and other countries are aware of that.'' Fitzwater said the United States was continuing to encourage other nations to freeze Iraqi assets and to institute economic sanctions against Baghdad. The United States also is urging a freeze on Kuwaiti assets to keep them away from Iraq. Arab leaders have warned against foreign intervention and have sought a diplomatic solution, but an emergency Arab League summit to discuss the crisis initially planned for Sunday in Saudi Arabia was postponed. Asked if the delay constituted a setback, Fitzwater said, ``It's difficult to know. The timing is a question for them to consider. We don't know all of the criteria or concerns that they had about holding the meeting versus at some later point. So it's just impossible to say.''

DOC.HEAD: Overeaters Anonymous Celebrates Freedom From Food in Gourmet Setting
DOC.TEXT: Holding the annual convention of Overeaters Anonymous in this city of rich food might seem like too much temptation, but for those attending it was more like a testimonial to the program. ``We recognize the irony and some of the temptations it presents,'' said Jorge Sever, executive director of Overeaters Anonymous. ``We aren't worried about it, however.'' A week after the chefs of the American Culinary Federation staged their 1990 Culinary Mardi Gras, Overeaters Anonymous gathered this weekend to celebrate the group's 30 years of helping people recover from compulsive overeating. ``It is ironic, but it's really neat in a way. It points out that our program isn't just about food. It's about how we're living our lives,'' said Kathy, who has been involved in OA for 10 years. Kathy, who like most members of the organization doesn't reveal her last name, said she weighed 218 pounds when she joined OA. She now weighs 125, though she's lived in this capital of cookery for two years. ``If you're fit emotionally and spiritually and every other way, you eat to enjoy it, not because you have to,'' said Kathy. ``New Orleans is known for its food and its restaurants. I'm sure some of our members will really enjoy it. Others will avoid it. We all have to do what's right for us.'' Organizers said 1,500 people from all over the world registered for the convention and its nearly 40 meetings and workshops. Overeaters Anonymous is divided into nine regions nationally, said Annette Mambuca, the group's publications editor. The conventions are rotated among the regions. When the southeastern region's turn came, New Orleans was selected _ ``strictly on the convention facilities and the appeal it would have for our members,'' Ms. Mambuca said. OA isn't the first group finding itself in conflict with New Orleans' rich food tradition. In March, 24,000 heart doctors gathered for the American College of Cardiology's convention, and New Orleans-style banquet menus had to be modified to reduce cholesterol levels. Overeaters Anonymous, which was started in January 1960 in Los Angeles, is patterned after the Alcoholics Anonymous program. ``The program is not really a diet club,'' Sever said. ``We don't provide a food plan or anything like that for our members. We offer support, we share in some of their griefs and in their joy of recovery. Some people feel they need some type of regimentation. In that case we tell them to see a doctor or a dietitian.'' OA does not charge fees or dues. Most groups take up a collection at meetings to cover expenses. The organization doesn't solicit or accept outside contributions. ``I'll never graduate from OA,'' Kathy said. ``Initially I went to lose weight. I stick around because of the spiritual and emotional growth.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Jailed For Locking Children In Apartment for Three Days
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Sunday jailed a woman who locked three of her children in an apartment for three days with no adult care and only a small amount of food. Marie-Rose Winterstein, 32, and her boyfriend, Gilbert Risser, 34, were ordered held until a hearing Thursday to determine if they would be prosecuted for depriving minors of proper care. The couple left their apartment in Forbach, near the French-Belgian border, on Tuesday, taking Winterstein's 5-year-old son with them. Left behind were Sonia, 12; Natacha, 7, and Michael, 20 months. Sonia made meals of noodles and eggs for the first two days, police said. On Thursday, neighbors in adjoining apartments responded to Sonia's appeals by passing food to their balcony, but they didn't summon authorities until Friday because the girl told them her mother was expected back soon. Neighbors said the couple had left the children unattended before, but for shorter periods. The children were reported in satisfactory condition Sunday at a hospital, where they were to stay pending resolution of the case against their mother.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Kills 108 in Southern China
DOC.TEXT: A tropical storm lashed southern China with strong winds and torrential rains, killing 108 people and flooding hundreds of thousands of acres of farmland, it was reported Sunday. Floods from tropical storm Tasha killed 39 people and injured 335 in Guangdong province alone, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The storm destroyed 25,200 houses in Guangdong and flooded 353,210 acres of farmland and seven cities from July 29 to Friday, the report said. Another 69 people were killed in Fujian province in floods that inundated 333,450 acres of farmland and caused damage estimated at nearly $83 million, it said. The two provinces sent teams to the affected areas to help with rescue and reconstruction work, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Repulses Rebel Attack, Killing 30
DOC.TEXT: Government troops and warplanes on Sunday repulsed a major assault on a military-held fort in the heart of Tamil rebel territory, killing at least 30 fighters, the army said. A rebel leader, meanwhile, denied his militia was responsible for the massacre Friday of 140 Moslem worshipers in two mosques in an eastern town, a newspaper reported. The rebels, who are members of the Tamil minority, are battling for an independent homeland in this Indian Ocean republic. The militants began their fight in 1983, claiming their community was being discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. At least 14,000 people have been killed during the civil war. Tamils, who are mostly Hindu, make up 18 percent of the population, while the mostly Buddhist Sinhalese, who control the government and the military, comprise 75 percent of the people. Moslems, who make up 7 percent of the population, claim neutrality in the civil war, but the rebels have accused them of siding with the government. On Sunday, at least 300 rebels attacked an 18th-century fort in Jaffna city with mortars, rockets and machine guns, the military reported. Government troops have been holding out in the fort for 55 days. Government troops called in air support and the fighting and intensive air attacks left at least 30 guerrillas dead, the army said. In a statement, the military said no government troops were killed in the fighting. There was no independent confirmation of the casualties and there were no reports from the rebels. The almost 200 soldiers in Jaffna Fort have been under siege since the fighting began on June 11. More than 3,000 combatants and hundreds of civilians have been killed in fighting since then. A rebel leader, meanwhile, denied his group was involved in the Friday massacre of 140 Moslem worshipers, the Sunday Times newspaper reported. The newspaper said a leader of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the main rebel militia, said in a telephone interview that the killing was carried out by a rival Tamil group to discredit the Tigers. The newspaper identified the leader as Karikalan, the political officer of the Tigers in the eastern district of Batticaloa. Most rebel leaders use only one name. At least 112 of the victims were buried Saturday. Twenty-eight of the 75 people injured in the attack later died, Sri Lanka's Sunday Times reported.

DOC.HEAD: Army Distributing Gas Masks to Civilians
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The army is stepping up its distribution of gas masks to civilians following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Israeli media reported Sunday. An army spokesman confirmed that soldiers have been distributing protective equipment against a possible chemical weapons attack but denied the move was linked to the invasion. In April, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to ``scorch half of Israel with poison gas,'' if his country were attacked. The Israeli military began an experimnetal distribution of gas masks shortly following Saddam's threat. ``The distribution of gas masks is part of a plan enacted several months ago and will continue until all residents in Israel hear explanations of what chemical warfare is,'' the spokesman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity in keeping with military regulations. He said a mass distribution effort was being considered, but added that no concrete decisions were made since Thursday's invasion by Iraq. But the left-wing Al Hamishmar newspaper reported that gas masks would be distributed to hundreds of thousands of homes by the year's end. The Haaretz daily said in a front-page story Sunday that army officers met secretly this weekend and decided to distribute gas masks in the Tel Aviv metropolitan area. That region, the most densely populated in Israel, is home to about 1.9 million of the country's 4.5 million people. It also reported that the army planned to start marketing videotapes explaining how to use the equipment. This past year an experimental distribution of gas masks was conducted in two cities, Ramat Hasharon, north of Tel Aviv and Sefad in northern Israel's Galilee. About half-a-million pupils in the nation's 2,200 schools were also taught how to use special anti-gas kits. Israel widely issued gas masks on a trial basis in 1979, but stopped the practice after it was discovered that the equipment was often used at masquerade parties and while painting cars. But Israelis began taking the issue more seriously after widespread allegations that Iraq used poison gas against its Kurdish minority during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war that ended in 1988. Iraq is one of four Arab countries believed to have chemical weapons, and possessed medium-range missiles. Egypt, Syria, and Libya are also believed to have chemical weapons. Israeli leaders, meanwhile, said they were closely following the military developments in Kuwait. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said he saw no need for Israel to intervene in the conflict but added that if Iraq sent troops into neighboring Jordan ``this would change the geostrategic situation for Israel and would require action on our part.''

DOC.HEAD: China Restores Ties With Indonesia, Seeks Regional Influence
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng departs Monday on an official visit to Indonesia and Singapore, seeking to enhance China's influence in the region. Long ostracized by the West for its violent suppression of pro-democracy protests and bypassed by the democratic revolutions that shook its socialist allies, China has sought to exert more influence in its traditional sphere of influence, Western diplomats say. China's aspirations have been encouraged by U.S. plans to reduce its military profile in the region, said the diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Beijing is anxious to counterbalance U.S. and Japanese influence in the region,'' said one diplomat. Another diplomat added: ``China ... sees itself as the pre-eminent power in Southeast Asia, and the pre-eminent cultural force. It decided it would be best to work on relations close to home.'' By securing normal ties with Indonesia and Singapore, Beijing has also scored a diplomatic coup against Taiwan, which it regards as a renegade province. While none of China's neighbors would accept a Chinese military presence on their territory, some are welcoming closer diplomatic ties. China and Indonesia are set to resume normal diplomatic relations on Aug. 8, nearly 23 years after Jakarta suspended ties with Beijing after an abortive Communist coup it blamed on Chinese influence. Following Indonesia's lead, Singapore is expected to establish diplomatic relations with Beijing before the end of the year. Both Singapore and Indonesia cited the promise of improved trade ties with Asia's most populous market as one reason for the rapprochement. Indonesia's total trade with China has more than doubled _ from $421 million to $918 million last year _ since the July 1985 signing of a memorandum of understanding between the two countries' chambers of commerce and industry. Indonesia's foreign minister, Ali Alatas, said he hopes to sign a new trade agreement during Li's visit Monday through Friday. Li's visit to Singapore, scheduled for Saturday through Aug. 13, is expected to further trade and investment ties developed over the past decade. Singapore, which is slightly larger than Chicago, is China's fifth-largest export market, much of it for re-export to other countries. Singaporean businessmen, many of them ethnic Chinese, have been encouraged by their government to invest more in China's manufacturing and tourism. Beijing's decision to stop supporting anti-government Communist rebels in the region, with the exception of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, has helped open the ways for better ties with neighboring states. Of the six members of Association of Southeast Asian Nations _ Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand _ only the sultanate of Brunei has not agreed to establish normal relations with Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban National Ballet Dancer, Husband Seek Asylum in Spain
DOC.TEXT: A top ballerina with the Cuban National Ballet and her husband were granted political asylum in Spain, a police spokesman said Sunday. It was the latest strain in relations between Spain and its former Caribbean colony, already tense over 18 Cubans being sheltered at Spain's embassy in the Cuban capital of Havana. The police spokesman at Madrid's Barajas Airport, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed that dancer Dagmar Moradillo and her husband, Alfredo Rodriguez, sought and received provisional political asylum Saturday at the police station. Rodriguez is a ballet lighting designer with the company. The conservative Madrid newspaper ABC also reported the defections. It said the dancer and her husband had arrived Saturday from the Spanish Mediterranean isle of Majorca, where the ballet company performed Friday. In an interview with ABC, the 29-year-old dancer said she was concerned authorities may fire her mother from her job at a Havana hospital. ``Now begins the future, something that didn't exist in Cuba,'' she told the paper. ``It's a no-way-out situation there, no objectives or possibilities. ``That's why we escaped ... we didn't see a future for ourselves or the children we desire,'' she said. The dancer and her husband told the paper they wanted to live in the United States. They have family in Miami, and the dancer believes she can continue her career. The couple joined the Cuban company in the mid-1970s. The Spanish-Cuban diplomatic conflict began early last month when disgruntled Cubans began seeking refuge in foreign embassies in Havana. The conflict is at a standstill, and Cuba continues to refuse to permit the asylum-seekers to leave the country, said a Spanish government spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with Foreign Ministry policy. Spain refuses to expel the 18 from its embassy.

DOC.HEAD: ^News Trickles Out from Tense Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Invading Iraqi soldiers have looted banks, supermarkets and car showrooms and an underground resistance has emerged, said some of the few callers who got through to Kuwait. Soldiers went on a looting spree Saturday in stores stocked with goods unavailable at home, said residents and foreign diplomats. Looters who hit car dealerships often drove off with luxury sedans. Soldiers also targeted banks and supermarkets, callers said. Residents said the resistance movement has been distributing leaflets at mosques to rally support for fighting the invaders. Some bloated bodies had yet to be removed from around the palace, which was bombarded for more than two hours during the invasion Thursday, residents said. At least 200 people were killed and wounded during the invasion, diplomats said. Reports that the toll was at least three times that could not be confirmed. Iraq announced Sunday that it was withdrawing some troops. Telephone lines went completely dead Friday morning, but a few phone calls trickled through Saturday. Kuwait TV returned to the air Saturday, heavy with support for the nine-man military Cabinet installed by Baghdad. Its new emblem is a flame. Diplomatic sources said Iraqi tanks and artillery began pulling out of the city center Saturday. But Iraqi tanks shelled al-Beda, a manmade island on the city's southern coast near the industrial center of Shuaiba, said one diplomat who insisted on anonymity. He did not know why it was shelled. Otherwise no gunfire was reported Saturday. The extent of damage from the invasion could not be determined, though many landmark buildings were scarred by shell holes. A woman living on the Kuwait University campus said the situation was ``very quiet, almost eerie, and tense.'' Iraqi soldiers were stopping cars and ``politely'' asking people to step out so they can check them, said the woman, speaking on condition of anonymity. She also said that workers, especially those at such prime installations as refineries, were allowed to go to work normally.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Postpones South American Trip
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has postponed indefinitely a five-nation trip to South America in mid-September because of deficit-reduction negotiations with Congress and other problems, administration officials said Sunday. Bush had been scheduled to visit Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela from Sept. 16-22. One official said Bush still hopes to make the trip by the end of the year but that may not be possible. Another official said the earliest rescheduling of the trip would be within a couple of months. Embassies in each country were notified over the weekend that the trip was being postponed, the officials said. Bush informed Uruguay President Luis Lacalle on Friday, Foreign Minister Hector Gros Espiell said. Latin leaders expected Bush during his visit to explain his proposal of a free trade zone from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego., U.S. Embassies have been working with foreign ministries on legislation expected to be ready for signing by mid-September, such as the lifting of bank secrecy laws to allow the investigation of accounts thought to be related to narcotics trafficking. Cancellation of September's visit comes amid the crisis in the Middle East caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. However, officials said the primary reason for the delay were the budget negotiations scheduled to resume in early September between the White House and Congress. The nearly three-month-old talks are at an impasse and were suspended while Congress and Bush vacation in August.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr told a friendly audience over the weekend that she must be the ``world's greatest singer.'' And why does she think that? ``Because my voice can stop a (bleeping) nation,'' Barr said Saturday in her first public stage performance since singing a shrill rendition of ``The Star Spangled Banner'' in San Diego. No hecklers or protesters were in the crowd of about 5,000 at the Riverfest outdoor stage at Harriet Island. One fan carried a sign that read, ``We love you Roseanne.'' Barr's rendition of the national anthem at a Padres baseball game drew boos from the crowd. She capped the performance by grabbing her crotch and spitting on the ground in what she said was a parody of a baseball pitcher. Commenting on the public backlash from her act in San Diego, Barr joked that she was ``recently released from the Betty Ford drug clinic.'' ``I didn't want to be on drugs,'' she said, ``but my publicist said it would help my comeback.'' Helen Corbett, a spectator from Bloomington, said there was ``too much of a fuss'' made about Barr's national anthem performance. ``Half the nation can't sing the national anthem any better than she did,'' Corbett said. Barr's 45-minute, profanity-laced act preceded a performance by 1950s rock 'n' roller Chuck Berry.

Actress Julia Roberts, who outraged many upstate South Carolinians by saying the region was racist, now says she was referring to just one incident. ``I was born in the South, so in no way am I trying to create a stereotype,'' Ms. Roberts said in a statement given to the Anderson Independent-Mail on Friday. Ms. Roberts, who is from Smyrna, Ga., said she was referring to an incident in which a black friend who entered an Abbeville restaurant with her was refused service. She added: ``I was shocked that this type of treatment still exists in America in the '90s _ in the South or anywhere else.'' In an interview in the Aug. 9 issue of Rolling Stone magazine, Ms. Roberts said Abbeville was ``horribly racist'' and a ``living hell.'' Ms. Roberts was in Abbeville in May filming ``Sleeping With the Enemy.'' She recently starred with Richard Gere in the box-office hit ``Pretty Woman.'' More than 100 upstate South Carolina residents last week contributed money for a $467 ad that appeared in Wednesday's issue of Variety. The ad appeared under the heading ``Pretty Woman? Pretty Low.'' ``Are there racists here?'' the ad said. ``Perhaps some, as there are throughout the world. But they do not define us.''

The Janet Jackson concert scheduled for Sunday evening at Iowa State University was postponed because the pop singer is ill, officials said. Ms. Jackson, a sister of pop superstar Michael Jackson, was being treated for an inner-ear infection. A spokesman at ISU's Hilton Coliseum said the singer also postponed a concert scheduled for Saturday night in St. Louis. Ms. Jackson is on a national tour to promote ``Rhythm Nation 1814,'' her second album.

Even though Kathy Swanson is suing Andrew Dice Clay for $6 million, she wants people to know the comedian who once was her husband used to be sweet. Ms. Swanson, who left her family's rural Iowa farm to seek success in Hollywood, said she and Clay met in 1980. Their first date included buying a bottle of wine at a convenience store and sitting in front of a fake log in his fireplace. They spent a chaste night together on the sofa, sleeping, she said. ``It was like he tied me to a pedestal. He was very protective of me, and that was fine at the time,'' Ms. Swanson said in an interview with The Des Moines Sunday Register. They lived together for four years, married in 1984 and were divorced two years later. Although her ex-husband _ whose act has been criticized as misogynist, homophobic and otherwise bigoted _ always tended to view women ``as barefoot, pregnant and walking 10 feet behind you,'' his barbs grew more vehement, she said. Ms. Swanson said Clay manipulated her and that she did not get her own lawyer when they divorced. Her lawyer now, Marvin Mitchelson, said the divorce decree paid off $4,000 in debts and paid Ms. Swanson $1,000 a month for 18 months. Her suit seeks $3 million in shared property and an equal amount in punitive damages. Clay's lawyers have declined to comment. Ms. Swanson, who played Mel Gibson's wife in the movie ``Lethal Weapon'' and had the lead in a music video for the group .38 Special, said Clay became angry when she considered a movie role when they were married. But despite the court battle, she said she wants people to know ``that I had a wonderful time with Andrew and that I am sorry that things had to end so bitterly when they were so sweet for so long.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Trial Focuses Attention on Race Relations in Nation's Capital
DOC.TEXT: The cocaine and perjury trial of Mayor Marion Barry has focused attention on race relations in the nation's capital, a city with a 70 percent black population and little recent history of racial strife. ``I think that there is a perception with a substantial number of the population that he is being picked on unfairly,'' said Kenneth Robinson, a local attorney who consulted with Barry's counsel. Robinson is white. ``I think the Barry trial is just another indication that people are very, very sensitive to race and how people are treated,'' said Ethelbert Miller, a poet who teaches at Howard University. Miller is black. A U.S. District Court jury began deliberating the Barry case Thursday afternoon. Two members, both men, are white. One of them has been chosen jury foreman. Barry admits that the trial has brought to the surface ``a simmering amount of polarization and racism that was already there.'' Some blacks agree with Barry's claim that he was the target of overzealous white prosecutors. Others feel betrayed by the mayor, who had claimed repeatedly that he didn't use drugs. ``The majority of whites are just plain annoyed and angry and just want this guy to go,'' D.C. Councilman Jim Nathanson said before the trial began. Nathanson, who is white, represents a predominantly white district. For all the talk about racial polarization, Barry is the one who was often credited with cooling the tempers that erupted after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968. Ten people died, 1,191 were reported injured and 7,650 were arrested in the city's worst riots. Washington was then 63 percent black. Some black leaders, Jesse L. Jackson among them, have suggested that the climate exists for a resurgence of racial violence in Washington if Barry is convicted. Barry himself said it will not. ``Those who would even talk about that don't represent me, don't represent what I stand for,'' he told reporters last week. ``You obviously don't realize that we have grown as a people the last 20 years. We will not destroy that which we have worked so hard to build up.'' ``To equate this to the violence that would occur when a white man killed Martin Luther King is asinine,'' Robinson said. ``People will talk about it in bars and on the street, but I just don't believe that it is going to happen.'' ``Some of the noise that you hear is sort of par for the course,'' said Sam Smith, the white publisher of the Progressive Review, a Washington opinion journal. ``It's just that more people are paying attention to it now.'' The presiding judge in the trial, Thomas Penfield Jackson, is white. One of the prosecutors, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin, is white. The other, Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts, is black. Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, is black. Barry has called the case ``a political lynching'' and a case of ``satanic, dirt-like tactics.'' Jackson called it part of an ``ugly pattern'' of ``white judicial leadership attacking black political leadership.'' NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks voiced a similar complaint. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said he believes in trying cases ``regardless of who the person is or what the political priorities are.'' The mayor and his allies have also sharply criticized news media coverage of the case. Abdul Alim Muhammad, a Muslim who is running for Congress in suburban Prince George's County, Md., said, ``What we are witnessing in D.C. is like an electronic lynching. In some respects, the media are no better than the red-necked tobacco chewing members of the Ku Klux Klan.'' Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, has shown his support for Barry by attending the trial despite efforts by the judge to have him barred as ``potentially disruptive.'' Barry, who broke into politics as a street organizer in the civil rights movement, has been mayor for 12 years. He is not seeking re-election, and six candidates are running to succeed him. When one of them, City Council Chairman David Clarke, was introduced at a rally for black South African leader Nelson Mandela, he was booed by members of the mostly black audience. Clarke is white. Although he still has a loyal following, especially among poor blacks, Barry is increasingly viewed as an embarrassment by members of Washington's large black middle class. Long-time civil rights advocate and educator Roger Wilkins, a past political supporter of the mayor, wrote recently in The Washington Post: ``Marion Barry used the elders and lied to the young. He has manipulated thousands of others with his cynical use of charges of racism to defend his malodorous personal failures.'' Robert Woodson, president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, said Barry ``has certainly created a racial situation out of something that I do not think was. He is exploiting tensions and in some cases creating tensions that otherwise would not have existed.'' Woodson, who is black, was a member of a White House council on private sector initiatives in the Reagan administration. The Rev. James Bevel, a Barry supporter who conducted prayer meetings in a tent outside the courthouse through much of the trial, said; ``It is not affecting basic race relationships or hostilities in black folks toward white people. I don't see that in the people I'm around.'' The Rev. A. Knighton Stanley, the black pastor of People's Congregational Church, said he avoids raising the issue of possible violence. ``Am I uneasy? My answer is yes,'' said Stanley. ``My judgment is we will not have it, and my prayer is that my judgment is right.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Reserve Captain Returns Son's Salutes
DOC.TEXT: Discipline is observed more closely in the Richardson family than in most others. Diane Richardson doesn't just give orders to her 19-year-old son, Don. She expects him to salute. ``He calls me `Captain Mom.' I call him `Private Son,''' said Capt. Diane Richardson, a 15-year member of the Army Reserve. For years her son said he wanted no part of military life. ``He was emphatic about not joining the Army,'' said Ms. Richardson, 38. ``He just didn't like being ordered around.'' But he joined the Army in March. He leaves Aug. 13 for a one-year tour of duty in South Korea as a private. The chance to become a food-service specialist changed his mind. ``It's going to be an experience,'' Richardson said. Even when the two are in uniform, Mom's captain's bars don't command absolute respect. ``It's a usual mother-son type deal,'' she explained. ``He doesn't speak to me because he doesn't think I'm saying anything. But he's a good kid.''

DOC.HEAD: Economist Predicts ``Mild Recession''
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Democratic economist Charles Schultze said Sunday that Iraq's invasion of oil-rich Kuwait could set off a ``mild recession'' in the United States. But he said the situation would become far worse if Iraqi power spreads and it comes to dominate world oil markets. Schultze, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Carter administration, said he did not expect severe oil and gasoline shortages of the type that developed in 1979. He said he does expect higher energy prices. ``The main thing we have to do is distinguish what's going on now, which is bad for our economy, and is going to raise oil prices and gasoline prices, but is not going to be catastrophic,'' Schultze said. But if (Iraq) is let go and what (could) happen in the long run really happens, then Katy bar the door,'' he said.'' ``So short run this is not a big deal economically,'' he said. ``Long run we've got real (potential) problems.'' Schultze made the comments on the ABC television news program, ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' Schultze said that if Saddam Hussein, Iraq's military ruler, were to overrun not only Kuwait but Saudi Arabia and the oil-rich emirates along the Persian Gulf, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries or OPEC would move from being merely a cartel to ``really a controlling monopoly.'' Schultze said that before Iraqi troops stormed across the border into Kuwait the U.S. domestic economy was ``probably on the edge of a recession.'' ``We might have muddled through without one,'' he said. Now, he said, ``My guess is that if nothing else happens it could kick over into a mild recession.'' ``We wouldn't like it; it would be costly,'' he said. ``But it wouldn't be huge.'' ``But if in the longer run the OPEC oil supplies are really organized by one person, then we could be in trouble in the long run seriously,'' Schultze said.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats May Press for German Unity This Week
DOC.TEXT: Signs were mounting Sunday that Social Democrats in the two Germanys _ the second-largest party in both countries _ may push for a unified Germany as early as this week. Horst Ehmke, deputy chairman of the West German Social Democrats, reportedly suggested the East German Social Democrats may propose instant unity during a special parliamentary session this week.
