Asked by the newspaper Bild whether the East German Social Democrats might make such a move during the Wednesday session in East Berlin, Ehmke reportedly replied: ``I don't know. I don't exclude it.'' The Social Democratic parties in both Germanys are in close consultation with one another. The East German Social Democrats are part of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's broad coalition government. The West German Social Democrats are the main opposition to Chancellor Helmut Kohl. On Saturday, the head of the West German Social Democrats, Hans-Jochen Vogel, said West Germany would have to ``respect'' a decision by East Germany's Parliament for an ``early joining'' to the west before all-German elections. Other West German Social Democrats have echoed that view in the past two days. The move is most likely an effort to improve the party's chances of winning the leadership of a united Germany when all-German elections take place. The Social Democrats' apparent maneuvering comes as Kohl presses to have all-German elections moved up from Dec. 2 to Oct. 14. Under that scheme, formal unity would occur immediately before the vote. Kohl's Christian Democrats want all-German elections to take place quickly to avoid a potential loss of voter support if the East German economy collapses. Joblessness in East Germany has climbed to more than 240,000 after the July 2 economic merger of the two Germanys and is expected to move much higher. Social Democrats are fighting to keep the elections from being moved up to Oct. 14. But the Social Democrats now say they would accept actual unification much sooner because of East Germany's economic problems. That would allow them to be perceived as embracing a process they have tried to slow, while still pushing for elections in December, when the economic woes are expected to be much worse. Whether all-German elections occur on Dec. 2 or Oct. 14 hinges on Kohl's ability to persuade the West German Parliament to make a constitutional change necessary for the earlier date. For that, Kohl needs a two-thirds majority vote he can't manage without the Social Democrats. Oskar Lafontaine, Kohl's Social Democratic rival for the chancellorship of a united Germany has vowed to block Kohl's plan. Kohl himself seemed to acknowledge that pushing the idea through West Germany's Parliament will be harder than expected. ``Kohl's panicky proposal clearly shows that he sees his chances vanishing every day,'' Lafontaine told the Sueddeutsche Zeitung in a report released to other news media in advance of Monday's publication. Seiters also announced that Kohl and Hans-Jochen Vogel, federal leader of the Social Democrats, would meet on Tuesday to try to reach agreement on the elections. The proposal to move up the all-German vote to Oct. 14 was made public Friday by de Maiziere, following consultations with Kohl.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say They Almost Fired on U.S. Troops During Mission
With AM-US-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebels said they nearly fired on U.S. military aircraft Sunday during an evacuation operation because they had not been informed of the mission. Earlier Sunday, rebel leader Charles Taylor appealled to all Liberians to ``oppose all foreign intervention'' and accused the U.S. of a mounting ``new colonization'' drive. But he made the comments before it was clear the U.S. planes were on an evacuation mission. More than 200 airborne U.S. Marines swept into Liberia early Sunday to evacuate Americans after Taylor's rival, Prince Johnson, ordered the seizure of foreigners, especially Americans, Britons, Indians and Lebanese, on Monday. Johnson said he hoped to provoke international intervention in the 7-month-old tribal war targeted at Liberian President Samuel Doe, who remained holed up in his mansion in Monrovia, the capital. Doe on Sunday welcomed the U.S. operation, saying it was needed to protect American lives. In the past he has asked the 2,100 Marines stationed offshore to help end the conflict. Tom Woewiyu, defense minister in Taylor's self-declared government-in-exile, said the United States in the past has kept Taylor's rebels informed of its moves but this time said nothing. ``We are protesting this,'' Woewiyu said. The United States is ``trying to sneak around and do a wholly clandestine operation which only confuses the situation ... a situation where an accident will be caused and someone will blame us.'' Liberian rebels were just receiving orders to fire on the incoming U.S. helicopters Sunday when they found out about the operation, Woewiyu said. He said the rebel order to fire was being sent by radio when a U.S. transmission broke into the frequency identifying the aircraft as U.S. planes. Once it was established the U.S. aircraft were in Monrovia for an evacuation and permission was given, ``they landed and they have been doing the evacuation with our forces watching and there has been no incident,'' Woewiyu said. In the confusion during the evacuation, Taylor broadcast an appeal over radio calling for a mass mobilization by Liberians ``to defend your country'' and ``oppose all foreign intervention.'' ``It is evident that all this is orchestrated to keep Samuel Doe in power,'' Taylor said in the broadcast from a station in the northern town of Yekepa. ``We are confronted with the challenge of a new colonization as in the times of slavery.'' Taylor has a much larger army than Johnson's, but thousands are young recruits with little training and they have been bogged down by government troops six miles east of Doe's mansion. Johnson's men had reached to within hundreds of yards of the presidential residence when they withdraw to confront Taylor's troops approaching from their rear. Leaders of seven West African states are scheduled to meet in Banjul, Gambia, on Monday to discuss the conflict and Nigerian proposals to send in a task force to end the war. About 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed in the fighting. On July 30, about 600 civilians in a Lutheran church compound were massacred. Witnesses blamed government troops, but the government said they were rebels dressed as government troops. The rebels accuse Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, of corruption.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6 p.m. EDT, TIME set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Thinks of Giving Presidency Another Go
DOC.TEXT: Democrats, get out your checkbooks and dig out those 1988 buttons, the Duke thinks he might want to give it another try. Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, he of the plummeting poll ratings and slumping state budget, hasn't ruled anything out for '92. In a television interview broadcast Sunday, the 1988 Democratic nominee sounded like a man ready to get up off the canvas and go another round. ``Can you ever see yourself running for President again?'' the governor was asked on C-SPAN, a cable TV public affairs network. ``Maybe. Maybe,'' Dukakis said. ``I don't think you rule it out, I don't think you rule it in,'' he said. ``Kitty and I are still relatively young, we've still got our health, we've got a lot of energy, it's an exciting and wondrous world out there these days, as we read about the cataclysmic changes every day internationally and otherwise.'' The comments were only a slight advance from what Dukakis has been saying all along since his crushing defeat at the hands of George Bush two years ago. ``Never say never,'' has been the consistent Dukakis line. ``I want to keep my hand in public life,'' he said in response to the latest queries. ``What form that takes I don't know.'' Marty Linsky, a political analyst at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government and a longtime acquaintance of Dukakis, found a dry way of depicting the governor's chances. ``There certainly doesn't seem to be much external data for it,'' Linsky said. He cited a recent presidential preference poll of Democratic National Committee members in which not a single member mentioned Dukakis. Dukakis is retiring from the governor's office in January after three terms. Polling data, editorials and political commentary seem to hold that up as a wise decision. Since losing to Bush, Dukakis has come home to a state beset by budget shortfalls, the specter of tax increases and an electorate angry with his administration. For now, Dukakis said, ``I want to finish up my final year as governor as strong as I possibly can, leave a good solid state for my successor, and then Kitty and I will kind of take a look at the world and decide where we go from here.''

DOC.HEAD: Philippines Places Troops on Alert Following Reports of Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Officials ordered troops to their barracks Sunday after intelligence reports said dissident soldiers would make another attempt to topple President Corazon Aquino, a military spokesman said. The spokesman, Lt. Col. Cresencio Maralit did not give details on the reported coup attempt, nor its duration. Mrs. Aquino has survived at least six coup attepts during her four-year term. ``Unconfirmed reports about another coup attempt by rebel elements prompted the Philippine Constabulary to raise alert status,'' Maralit told reporters. The red alert was ordered in the headquarters of the army, air force, constabulary and the Capital Command, said Brig. Gen. Lisandro Abadia, operations chief of the Armed Forces of the Philippines. The Northern Luzon Command in Tarlac province and the armed forces training command in Rizal province outside Manila were also included in the order. In a red alert, soldiers are ordered to barracks. Mobile patrols were stepped up in the capital, said Capital Command chief Brig. Gen. Marino Filart. On Dec. 1, mutineers belonging to the Reform the Armed Forces Movement, launched a nine-day coup attempt that killed 113 people and wounded about 600. Since last year's failed coup, renegades have been threatening to strike. But a devastating earthquake that rocked Luzon island last month prompted dissidents to offer a cease-fire to help rebuild the nation. Mrs. Aquino rejected the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: BU President Adds Press to List of Gubernatorial Foes
DOC.TEXT: Democrat John Silber's shoot-from-the-hip style has transformed him from a candidate who barely qualified for the Massachusetts primary election ballot into a central character in its governor's race. The outspoken Boston University president dominated headlines again last week, this time by taking aim at the headline writers. Silber stormed into the cafeteria of The Boston Globe to announce he would stop participating in candidate forums sponsored by the Globe and by the Boston Herald. The reason, he said, was that the newspapers were distorting his views. ``There's one thing to be said for live television,'' said Silber, who is on leave from his post at BU, where he was president for 20 years. ``There is no editing, and there is no way of putting a person's thumb on the scales.'' And with that, the 63-year-old philosopher and administrator who refuses to talk political ``plastic'' once again made himself the issue. According to Silber, he is running against a former state attorney general and the lieutenant governor in the Democratic primary, as well as a press that focuses mainly on sensational comments instead of his overall views. He has made blunt remarks about everything from welfare to feminists, giving him a public profile distinctly different from the Democrat he hopes to replace, retiring three-term Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. The remark that created the biggest furor came during an early Globe forum on health care. In commenting on how best to distribute health care funds, he referred to extraordinary and costly health care measures to prolong the life of the elderly. He then let loose with what has come to be known as a ``Silber shocker.'' ``When you've had a long life, and you're ripe, then it's time to go,'' he said. Silber cried foul when one of his Democratic opponents, former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti, used the quote in a campaign ad. Back in January, in the midst of putting forth the view that Massachusetts' welfare policies were attracting people from out-of-state, Silber said: ``Why should Lowell be the Cambodian capital of America? It is extraordinary. Why should they all be concentrated in one place?'' And more recently, at a forum on women's issues, he said in response to questions about judicial appointments: ``I would not put a white supremacist on the court for fear a black could not get a fair trial in his court. Neither would I put somebody like Louis Farrakhan on the bench who I think might discriminate against whites. Likewise, I would not appoint Gloria Steinem to the bench.'' That brought him criticism for lumping Steinem with Farrakhan and white supremacists. As the newspaper forums progressed, Silber became the issue _ even when he missed one and left the field open for Bellotti and Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, the third Democrat seeking the governor's seat. After Silber dropped out of the forum, his opponents immediately said the academic administrator, making his first run for public office, couldn't take the rough-and-tumble of political debate. ``If you can't stand the political heat, John, then maybe you should get out of the campaign kitchen,'' Murphy said. Public opinion polls have shown Silber and Bellotti in a dead heat, with Murphy slightly behind in the running for the Sept. 18 primary. In the Republican race, House Minority Leader Steven Pierce has held a comfortable lead over his lone opponent, former U.S. Attorney William Weld. But polls also showed Pierce well behind Silber and Bellotti. Former U.S. Sen. Paul Tsongas welcomed Silber's entry into the race, anticipating Silber's presence would elevate the level of debate. But he said Silber must share the blame when the substance of his remarks is lost. ``The media has run with things and has blown certain statements out of proportion, but `twas ever so,'' Tsongas said. ``That will always be the case if you speak in terms that lend themselves to that sort of thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Imposes Ban on Iraqi Oil
DOC.TEXT: Japan on Sunday imposed tough sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait, including a ban on oil imports and Japanese exports to the two countries. The unprecedented Japanese move, which significantly broadened a U.S.-supported campaign to isolate Iraq for its invasion, followed an announcement by China that it would not sell arms to Iraq. Italy and Spain _ two European Community countries most dependent on foreign crude oil _ also announced Sunday they would follow EC guidelines and impose sanctions. In Kuwait, the Iraqi-installed provisional government, in a statement carried by the Iraqi News Agency, told other countries to refrain from taking ``punishing measures'' against it or Iraq. The provisional government said countries ``have to remember they have interests and citizens in Kuwait'' and said it was prepared to close embassies and cut diplomatic relations with offending nations. The United States already has banned oil imports from Kuwait and Iraq and frozen both countries' assets in the United States. Japan said it will suspend loans and ban Japanese investment and financing in both Iraq and Kuwait, and freeze Iraqi assets in Japan, chief government spokesman Misoji Sakamoto said. Iraq became eligible in February for $2.67 billion in Japanese government credits, which it had not yet received. ``International conflicts must be settled peacefully. From this standpoint, we strongly denounce the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait,'' Sakamoto said. ``The government will fully support international efforts to settle the dispute through negotiations.'' In Washington, the White House hailed Japan's decision. It said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu called President Bush on Sunday to inform him of the sanctions. ``These unprecedented measures undertaken by Japan are in step with those that the United States and other countries have put in place against Iraq for its blatant aggression against Kuwait,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``The president welcomed Prime Minister Kaifu's and the Japanese Cabinet's decision and expressed confidence that such measures will help intensify international pressures aimed at achieving the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait,'' Fitzwater said. On Saturday, Bush telephoned Kaifu to ask for Japan's support in sanctions against Iraq, and all 100 members of the U.S. Senate signed a letter urging Tokyo to join other nations that have imposed sanctions. The sanctions, which exceeded those imposed Saturday by the European Community, are the toughest that postwar Japan has ever imposed, the Japan Broadcasting Corp. reported. News reports said the decision had been delayed because of differences of views within the government. The Foreign Ministry reportedly urged the government to join its Western allies in imposing sanctions, while the trade ministry warned of resulting damage to Japan's economy. Japanese newspapers said some trade ministry officials had expressed concern that sanctions on Iraq would push up oil prices in Japan and worsen chances for Baghdad's repayment of $4.6 billion in outstanding debts with Japan. Much of that is held by the private sector. Japan depends on foreign sources for 99 percent of its oil needs, and imported an average of 260,000 barrels a day, or 6.2 percent of its total consumption, from Iraq in the first quarter of this year. It obtained 5 percent of its oil from Kuwait, or 210,000 barrels a day, according to the trade ministry. On Friday, the Japanese government instructed banks and other financial institutions to block Iraqi access to the estimated $20 billion in Kuwaiti assets held in Japan. Following that decision, officials initially said they would wait to decide on further measures until the U.N. Security Council takes action on a resolution calling for sanctions. The council may discuss the resolution on Monday. In Beijing, the official Xinhua news agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying China supported the U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and would therefore not sell arms to Iraq. Spain's foreign ministry issued a communique Sunday saying Spain would require government approval for any foreign transfer of Kuwaiti assets in Spain and would soon freeze Iraqi assets. The communique said the measures were in line with the EC sanctions, which included an oil embargo on Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, a halt on arms sales to Iraq and the suspension of cooperation with Iraq in the military, technical and scientific fields. Nearly 11 percent of the EC's oil imports last year were from Iraq and Kuwait. In Italy, Justice Minister Giuliano Vassalli said Italy agreed to freeze Iraqi assets.The government on Friday froze Kuwaiti assets held in Italy and suspended arms shipments to Iraq. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arms supplier, announced Thursday it was ending arms sales to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Klansman, Impeached Black Judge Join Newspaperman in Florida Race
DOC.TEXT: A former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon, an impeached black federal judge and a self-described ``salty old newspaperman'' are battling in a primary campaign for a state Cabinet post that they insist won't focus solely on race. But the ex-judge, Alcee Hastings of Miami, said the last-minute entry of John Paul Rogers, former United Klans of America leader, into the Democratic primary for Florida secretary of state has forced him to switch to a campaign based on civil rights because of the emotions a Klansman can stir. ``I'm not going to let him get a free ride,'' Hastings said. ``I didn't want to run a civil rights campaign. The color of my skin shouldn't have anything to do with the issues I'm presenting.'' Hastings said he takes Rogers seriously, but can see some humor in the contrast between an avowed racist and a black liberal former judge. ``If Rogers doesn't burn any crosses in my community, I won't spit any watermelon seeds in his,'' Hastings said. Rogers, who entered the race just before the deadline July 20; Hastings; and former Tallahassee Democrat editorial writer Jim Minter are seeking the Democratic nod in the Sept. 4 primary to oppose Republican incumbent Jim Smith for secretary of state. The post is one of six Florida Cabinet positions elected statewide. The main duties of the job are to run the state's elections, keep corporate records and file financial disclosure forms turned in by elected and appointed officials. But there's more to it than just that: As one of the Cabinet posts, the office also shares power with the governor on a wide range of statewide issues, from environmental conservation to education. Smith, who only recently switched to the GOP, got more than 2.6 million votes in the 1986 election and will be a favorite against any of the three Democrats. Rogers, a Lake Wales barber and real estate agent, said he left the Klan 2{ years ago. Rogers, who has unsuccessfully run for the state House and for a couple of local offices, refused to renounce the Klan's supremacist philosophy but said race and Hastings didn't figure in his decision to run. ``I hope people won't vote for or against me based on race,'' Rogers said. ``I haven't injected it at all, and I don't plan to. I hope people will vote on the issues.'' Florida Democratic Party Chairman Simon Ferro has flatly declared the party would never support the ex-Klansman if he's the nominee. Yet Ferro says he would have no problem backing Hastings, who was aquitted of bribery charges in federal court but impeached in 1989 by the Senate over claims of an alleged payment to reduce sentences for racketeers. Hastings has always maintained his innocence. ``He was impeached, but that doesn't take away his rights to elective office and his right to have the voters judge his abilities and record,'' Ferro said. ``It does not go to the core problem of a person belonging to a hate organization.'' Rogers has tried to turn the tables on Ferro by claiming discrimination. ``I consider this to be highly prejudicial and insensitive bigotry,'' Rogers said. Hastings has concentrated his campaign in South Florida, where he appeals to solid voting blocs of minorities who agree with his claim that the government railroaded him. ``People are empathetic, sympathetic when they hear the facts of the case. They are outraged,'' he said. Minter hopes to benefit from the clash between his two opponents. Minter began covering politics for The Miami Herald in 1968. He has spent time in state government, including a stint working for former Secretary of State George Firestone and some time as a speechwriter for former Gov. Reubin Askew. He resigned from the editorial board of the Talahassee Democrat to join this year's campaign. ``I'm the Tallahassee pro here,'' Minter said. ``I have been an insider in state government, and I've covered it as a newspaperman.''

DOC.HEAD: 34 Injured When Passenger Train Derails
DOC.TEXT: A passenger train traveling from Berlin to Dresden derailed Sunday and four cars tumbled down an embankment, injuring 34 people, East Germany's news agency said. The train was traveling near Boehla, just northwest of Dresden, when it derailed, ADN reported. Dresden is about 125 miles south of Berlin. The news agency said 34 people were injured and that 25 of them were taken to a hospital. The cause of the derailment was not immediately known.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EDT, TIME set by source
DOC.HEAD: Report Criticizes Federal Rural Development Policy
DOC.TEXT: A dearth of federal dollars and good program management means rural and small-town Americans continue to suffer needlessly from poverty and pollution, a year-long study concludes. The report by the Center for Community Change, criticized the Farmers Home Administration for being run by people lacking backgrounds in ``finance, civil engineering and organizing,'' and blamed the Reagan administration for serious funding cutbacks. The FmHA, an Agriculture Department Agency that has its roots in the Great Depression of the 1930s, handles a variety of farm, housing and community programs. ``Federal support for rural development was cut by nearly 70 percent during the Reagan administration,'' said Robert Rapoza, who directed the study. ``Yet the majority of the remaining funds failed to reach the neediest rural communities. The federal response to these communities has been plainly inadequate.'' The report _ ``Searching for the Way That Works'' _ said rural problems include: _Unemployment, adjusted to include underemployment, is one-third higher than in the cities. _Rural Americans are more likely to be poor. One-third more rural people than urban residents are below the poverty line. _Ninety-seven percent of the nation's rural residents rely on ground water for drinking. Yet, a 1984 survey by the Environmental Protection Administration found two-thirds of the wells were contaminated. _Almost two million rural residents live in substandard housing, usually lacking adequate plumbing. _Maternal and infant mortality rates are substantially higher than in urban areas and are rising at faster rates. ``Rural residents are, as a group, less educated, less healthy and less skilled than their urban counterparts,'' the report said.''They operate in a comparatively static, more conservative business environment, and they receive less help from Washington.'' The center, a non-profit advocacy group for low-income rural people, conducted the study with a grant from the Ford Foundation. Joe O'Neill, a spokesman for the FmHA, said the agency had not had the opportunity to study the report. But he said, ``We're always pleased to get these kinds of studies ... and they can be very useful.'' The report criticized the FmHA for not targeting more of its resources to poor communities to help build water and sewer systems, health centers, fire houses and businesses. These programs add up to about $900 million this year. According to the report, poverty-level communities got only 2 percent to 3 percent of total FmHA loans and grants for water and sewer facilities between 1985 and 1988. The report said one reason for not targeting on the poorest communities is the way FmHA uses poverty data. While the agency adjusts the poverty line upward each year, it uses 1980 census numbers to determine the average income of individual communities, it said. Thus, some communities whose average income exceeded the poverty level in 1980 now fall under today's higher poverty line. The effect, according to the report, is that those communities qualify for FmHA assistance, even though others are much poorer. Programs operated by the Environmental Protection Agency also were criticized for failing to provide more help for rural areas to meet federal water standards. ``EPA figures indicate that two-thirds of rural water supplies violate agency drinking water standards,'' said Maureen Kennedy, principal author of the report. ``Given this need, it is disturbing that the EPA has naot provided more support to rural areas.'' The report hedged on recommending a vast reorganization of federal rural development programs, such as blending them all into one super agency. But it did propose some administrative changes within USDA's hierarchy. Also, it said many communities lack the know-how for getting access to federal programs that might help them develop. Futher, the report said most FmHA staff people come from agricultural backgrounds ``despite the fact that these programs demand training in finance, civil engineering and organizing.'' Consequently, ``FmHA should strengthen its substantive training programs, but more importantly, the agency should focus its recruiting efforts on those with backgrounds appropriate to the changing needs of the agency,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Zen Bakery Turns Cookie Making Into a Religious Experience
LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Food critics often liken Bernard Glassman's gourmet cakes and tortes to paradise. But this Brooklyn-born Zen Buddhist abbot is concerned with earthly missions, like providing job skills and housing for the disadvantaged and trying to save South American rain forests. Browsers at Bloomingdale's, weekenders in Long Island's fashionable Hamptons, and diners at Sardi's regularly savor Glassman's Greyston Bakery goodies, which are sold in 300 gourmet shops and restaurants nationwide. Greyston also provides the Vermont-based Ben & Jerry's ice cream company with the brownies that go into its Chocolate Fudge Brownie ice cream. And soon, the two socially conscious companies will market a new chocolate-chip cookie, which they hope will not only taste good but help save trees in the Brazilian rain forest and provide work for the homeless in this New York suburb. Greyston and its sibling companies have taught job skills to some 200 homeless and those at risk of losing their homes since 1982. Come fall, the company plans to use its profits and federal and state aid to renovate buildings near the bakery, which will be owned and managed by the formerly homeless tenants. Glassman describes the entrepreneurial effort as a mandala, or circle of activities, fostering jobs, social action and interfaith expression. The term mandala symbolizes a wholeness for which one strives in Buddhism, a religion and philosophic system which teaches that right thinking and self-denial will enable the soul to reach Nirvana _ a divine state of release from misdirected desire. The Zen sect seeks to attain an intuitive illumination of mind and spirit through meditation. All of the profits from the bakery and two other Zen-operated businesses _ one that trains minority construction workers and another that trains poorly paid office workers for jobs in the bakery and construction company _ goes into the Greyston Family Inn, a Zen-run social services agency. Glassman, who became a Zen monk in 1970 and quit his aerospace engineer job a few years later, oversees agency operations from the bakery, a former lasagne factory in a rundown section of downtown Yonkers. Glassman, who has slipped on a white smock that identifies him as the ``sensei'' or teacher, says he started the bakery with $40,000 from the Yonkers Private Industry Council. When it started in 1983, the bakery had sales of $282,000. This year, Glassman expects to bring in $1.8 million. Glassman said initial sales were made on the strength of the product, not on the activist philosophy, but that's changing. ``Only in the last few years has the fact that we're involved in social action even been noticed,'' he said. Three years ago, Glassman met Ben Cohen, co-founder of Ben & Jerry's, at a gathering of activist entrepreneurs. The two hit it off, and the brownie deal was quickly sealed. Soon, Greyston will begin making chocolate chip cookies with nut flour, a leftover from a Ben & Jerry's offshoot that uses Brazil nuts, grown in the Amazon rain forest, for ``Rainforest Crunch'' candy and ice cream. The businessmen believe that promoting nuts as a cash crop will encourage Brazilians to maintain the rain forest. ``Eat a cookie, save a tree,'' proclaims Glassman. Bakery workers, who include 30 non-Zen people from the neighborhood, come from El Salvador, India, Haiti, Puerto Rico. Carmelo Pagan, who worked his way up from dishwasher to bakery supervisor, calls the company ``amazing _ the friendship, the togetherness. We're trying to help the community.'' Millie Medina spun a lemon mousse cake on a pedestal, smoothing the buttercream, carving a design on the side and piping sophisticated swirls onto the top. With a shy smile, she said she used to be on welfare, but now, her friends are impressed by her achievements. ``And,'' she added, ``so am I.''

DOC.HEAD: Papua New Guinea, Rebels Sign Peace Accord
DOC.TEXT: Papua New Guinea and separatists on the island of Bougainville have signed a peace accord that could end a two-year war that has claimed more than 100 lives, New Zealand announced Sunday. The reported agreement followed peace talks on a New Zealand naval supply ship. A brief New Zealand government statement said the accord had been signed Sunday by Papua New Guinea and rebel leaders but gave no other details. The campaign began in 1988 when militants demanding a referendum on secession. A state of emergency was declared on June 26, 1989, and hundreds of soldiers were sent to the island in an attempt to put down the rebellion. But government security forces were withdrawn in March of this year, and a unilateral declaration of independence was made by the rebels two months later. The government had offered to restore essential services but demanded that general duty police be allowed back on the island. Bougainville leaders wanted a resumption of key services such as health care, education, telecommunications and banking as a condition for further talks.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Try To Free Marine Who Confessed To Drug Use Though Test Was Negative
DOC.TEXT: A Marine who pleaded guilty to using LSD on a Hawaii military base is serving five years in the brig even though a urine test showed no trace of drugs in his body. The parents of Pfc. Charles Serauskas, 21, of Stone Lake in northwestern Wisconsin have already spent $20,000 to bring an appeal. They say their son was still drunk and suffering from depression when he confessed to using and distributing LSD, or what he thought was LSD, at a barracks party last Oct. 13. Court records indicate that no drugs were found on Serauskas, and a urinalysis taken just hours his arrest on the night of the party turned up no sign of the drug. The sample has since been destroyed. ``We are going to fight them,'' said Serauskas' father, Leonard. ``I can't believe in this country you can be convicted when there is no evidence against you.'' ``Their son confessed he's guilty,'' countered Capt. Leonard Ryan, a spokesman for the Marine Corps Air Station at Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii, where Serauskas was arrested. ``In that case, there doesn't have to be evidence.'' Military records show that five other Marines who testified they received LSD from Serauskas were tested for drugs just hours after the party, and no evidence of drugs was found in their urine, either. Serauskas made a second confession at a sentencing hearing, but his family claims he was given bad advice by his military lawyer who advised him to plead guilty in hopes of getting a lenient sentence of no more than two years. Instead, Serauskas was sentenced to seven years, later reduced to five years, in the Pearl Harbor guardhouse. An appeal is pending before the Military Court of Review in Washington. If it fails, the case will be taken through civilian courts, the family said. Serauskas drank at least a case of beer and some whiskey at the party. With a confession of intent to use drugs, physical evidence was unnecessary, the military argued. Chief Warrant Office Randy Gaddo, a spokesman for Marine Corps headquarters in Washington, said a person's intent to commit a crime is considered to be evidence in both military and civilian courts, but ``the intent would weigh in with other evidence and other circumstances.'' The Serauskas family allege that the military's witnesses were intimidated. ``This case isn't a legal technicality. This case is a lack of evidence,'' said Robert Finlay, a Hawaii lawyer hired by the family. ``He is the farthest thing from a dope dealer that ever was,'' Finlay said. ``Maybe he is guilty as hell, but they sure couldn't prove it.'' Finlay said he has found evidence that the five other Marines were threatened by military officers to testify against Serauskas or risk being sent to the brig on various charges. Military prosecutors acknowledged that the five were questioned before a panel of seven officers. Court records indicate they were urged to tell the truth and prison punishment was discussed. The five were later given honorable discharges. The military judge who reviewed and then denied Serauskas' motion for retrial made no reference to the threats or the discharged soldiers. He ruled Serauskas was competent and understood the implications of his guilty plea. In transcripts from his court-martial, Serauskas, an artillery cannoneer, told the judge he purchased what he believed were 14 doses, or ``hits,'' of LSD from a fellow Marine. He told the judge he ate three hits. ``It made me kind of paranoid, sir, and I felt high, sir; see colors, the walls move,'' he said. According to court records, Serauskas had received several Marine citations during his three-year career. But he also had been cited for unexcused absences from a therapy program, drunken driving and making false statements. Before his arrest, his rank had been reduced from lance corporal to private first class in a disciplinary action.

DOC.HEAD: Conflicting Reports on Prisoners Linked to Western Hostages ^With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomatic sources said Sunday that Iraq may have executed 15 pro-Iranian terrorists whose freedom was demanded by factions holding Western hostages in Lebanon. But there were conflicting reports of the fate of the terrorists, who had been held in a Kuwaiti prison until Iraq's invasion of the emirate Thursday. Other diplomats said the Kuwaiti prisoners had been taken to Baghdad, and a third report said the Shiite Moslem prisoners escaped during the invasion. The pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, has repeatedly demanded that comrades jailed in Kuwait for bombing the U.S. and French embassies be released before it will free Western hostages. Seventeen men, mostly Iranian and Iraqi Shiite Moslems, were jailed in Kuwait in February 1984 for the Dec. 12, 1983, car bombings that killed five people and wounded 86. Two were released in February 1989 after serving five-year sentences. The Kuwaitis have repeatedly refused to free any of the others, including three who'd been condemned to death but whose sentences have not been carried out. The Kuwaitis have identified the bombers as members of the pro-Iranian Ad-Dawa, Arabic for Islamic Call, an Iraqi group that seeks to topple Saddam's government in Baghdad. Diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sunday they believed the 15 had been executed because of their membership in Ad-Dawa. The report could not be confirmed by official sources. However, Kuwaiti Embassy officials in Amman, Jordan, citing reports from ``reliable, official and political sources in Kuwait,'' said the prisoners were seized by Iraqis and taken to Baghdad, apparently to be used by President Saddam Hussein and used as a bargaining chip. A senior Kuwaiti Embassy official, speaking to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said official reports to the embassy said that Iraq seized the prisoners on Saturday. Iraqi Embassy officials said they had no information on that report. Radio Monte Carlo said Arab press sources had quoted a foreign resident of Kuwait as saying that the 15 were among 1,300 prisoners who escaped during the turmoil of the invasion. Forty-five political prisoners were reportedly among the escapees. That report also could not be confirmed by oficial sources. On Friday, the ABC television network reported that the prisoners were freed after the invasion, but gave no further details. The Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, believed to be the umbrella group for factions holding 16 Westerners hostage in Lebanon, withheld comment on that report. The longest held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Official Warns Turkey not to Cut Iraqi Pipeline
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A top Iraqi official warned Turkey on Sunday not to cut two pipelines in Turkey that carry more than half of Iraq's total oil exports. President Bush had suggested Friday that Turkey could close the pipelines to protest Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan told reporters that ``a ``a Turkish decision to shut down the pipeline would create mistrust'' between the two countries. ``In the case of an economic embargo or a military intervention, those who take these actions would be the losing party,'' he added. Ramadan met with President Turgut Ozal during his four-hour visit to the capital of Ankara. A spokesman for Ozal, Kaya Toperi, said Ramadan delivered a message from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein explaining why Iraq invaded. There was no further information on the message. The Turkish presidential office said Ozal, in his meeting with Ramadan, called on Iraq to adopt ``a realistic and constructive attitude urgently.'' President Bush said Friday it was ``certainly an option'' for Turkey to cut the Iraqi pipelines. Bush spoke by telephone to Ozal on Friday and Saturday. On Saturday, Ozal told reporters: ``There have been no demands from the United States for the closure of the pipeline. Such a demand is out of question. ``It is wrong to relate the issue (Iraqi invasion) with the closure of the pipeline,'' Ozal said. ``I explained (to Bush) that it was not that simple.'' Ramadan said he believed Turkey would continue to say neutral in the Persian Gulf. Turkey, which borders both Iran and Iraq, remained neutral throughout the eight-year Persian Gulf war. Iraq exports 2.7 million barrels of oil daily and 1.6 million barrels of that oil flows through Turkey. Turkey obtains 60 percent of its crude oil imports from Iraq. Turkey earns $250 million from Iraq annually for operating the pipeline.

DOC.HEAD: American Says Saudis Have Deployed Tanks Toward Kuwait Border
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has deployed 200 to 300 tanks toward its border with Kuwait, where Iraqi armored forces were reported to have moved into position, said an American technician who returned Sunday from Saudi Arabia. In addition, he said, the families of American civilian employees at a Saudi military base in the northern desert had been moved to Riyadh, the Saudi capital, and ``all others are on notice to evacuate.'' The American, who left Saudi Arabia on Saturday, spoke with The Associated Press, after arriving at Kennedy International Airport, on condition that he not be identified. He said he saw the tanks moving out of King Khalid Military City, a large Saudi military complex in the desert about 80 miles southwest of the point where the borders of Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia come together. A former U.S. commander in the Persian Gulf said the deployed tanks probably were drawn from a ``rapid deployment force'' maintained at the Saudi base, known as KKMC, by the six member countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council. George B. Crist, a retired Marine Corps general who formerly headed U.S. Central Command, the overall headquarters for American forces in the region, said it was ``a safe bet'' that the council force was ordered into the field. ``That's just what it was up there for,'' he said in a telephone interview. The unit includes two brigades, each with about 5,000 men and 100 or more U.S.-built M-1 and M-48 tanks. One brigade is all-Saudi and the other consists of single battalions from Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and the Sultanate of Oman, under Saudi command. The Gulf Cooperation Council set up the rapid deployment force several years ago as part of a mutual assistance agreement, but this apparently would be its first use in a battlefield situation. The American technician, who works at the base, said the deployment apparently occurred Friday, a day after the Iraqis invaded Kuwait and deposed its government, forcing the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to flee to Saudi Arabia. The Iraqis on Friday advanced some troops and tanks to within a few miles of the Saudi border, according to U.S. officials in Washington. The American said there had been no reports on how far apart the two forces were. The Saudi military complex, which does not appear on maps, lies off a main north-south road. It is about 35 miles in circumference and has a population of several thousand people, mostly Saudi military. The source said there had been about 80 American civilian technicians at the Saudi base, and 30 to 40 U.S. military personnel training Saudi pilots to fly UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters. There also is a small contingent of French missile technicians, he said. Two Americans who went to Kuwait from the base the day before the Iraqi invasion found themselves trapped and are still there, he said. ``We were able to talk to them once before the phone was cut off,'' he said. ``They were in a hotel in Kuwait and the embassy was telling them just to sit tight.''

DOC.HEAD: German History Written for Speed Readers
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Just when it seemed it could travel no faster, the blinding pace of German unification appears ready to put on another burst of speed. Blink, and you may miss history. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl punched the fast-forward button once again last week when he said that the two German nations should elect a single government on Oct. 14. That's seven weeks sooner than the already quick Dec. 2 election date that Kohl proposed earlier this year. Then, as now, the opposition Social Democrats in both countries have opposed the move, saying it would require too much tinkering with West Germany's election laws. But Horst Ehmke, deputy chairman of the West German Social Democrats, reportedly left open the possibility the East German Social Democrats may propose an instant unity during a special parliamentary session this week. Asked by the newspaper Bild whether the East German Social Democrats might make such a move during the Wednesday session in East Berlin, Ehmke reportedly replied: ``I don't know. I don't exclude it.'' Both Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats and the left-leaning Social Democrats are using the timing and sequence of German unity to enhance their own political fortunes. But behind the bluster is one issue that is pushing the process ever faster: whether East Germany has the economic strength, or the political will, to continue as a sovereign nation for very much longer. The young democratic government has become increasingly distressed over its empty coffers and the plight of its industries trying desperately to tread water in the nation's one-month-old free market. West Germany, which already has commited $71 billion to unification, has turned down East German pleas for additional help. There is a growing feeling in East Germany that the country should dissolve itself and unify soon, so its financial situation becomes the total responsibility of the Bonn government. Even if elections for a single government are held on Oct. 14, actual unification could take place much sooner. It is up to East Germany to enact unification. That will be done when its Parliament approves a clause in the West German constitution that will allow it to accede to its bigger neighbor. Right now, East German joblessness, while climbing, is being kept artificially low by a West German-financed program to keep workers on payrolls at shortened hours and lower wages. Without that program, unemployment would likely be at more than 10 percent, rather than the 2.7 percent it was officially estimated at last month. Joblessness is expected to eventually top out next year at perhaps 30 percent or 40 percent. Kohl's Christian Democrats want all-German elections to take place quickly to avoid a potential loss of voter support when the East German economy collapses. For that reason, the Social Democrats are fighting to keep the elections from being moved up to Oct. 14. But the Social Democrats also say now that they would accept actual unification much sooner because of East Germany's economic problems. That would allow them to be perceived as embracing a process they have tried to slow, while still benefiting politically from elections in December, when the economic woes are expected to be much worse. There is another wild card that could, though unlikely, throw the whole process out of whack. Oct. 14 is the date already set for East Germany to elect and create five state governments so the country can fit into the federal system in West Germany, which now has 11 states. Once those five state governments are created, political analysts say, they can technically vote individually whether to unify with West Germany. That means a state, if it wants, could decide that its particular industrial or agricultural economy needs to be attached to wealthy West Germany right now, not in December. That may be another reason why Kohl wants national elections on the day East German state elections are held, less than three weeks before the first anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: he said.
DOC.TEXT: Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said there was no indication that Iraq had sent its battle-hardened forces into Saudi Arabia, a critical world oil supplier, although Sen. David Boren said there had been minor incursions he described as ``sort of putting a foot across.'' Tens of thousands of Iraqi troops were reported massed in Kuwait near the Saudi border. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said fresh intelligence reports indicated an additional 18 Iraqi divisions moving south toward Saudi Arabia. But Bush said he had not heard such reports. After stepping out of his Marine One helicopter, Bush read a note handed to him by Richard N. Haass, a National Security Council senior director for Near Eastern Affairs, before facing reporters. Bush, juggling developments in two crisis-ridden regions of the world, also issued orders for U.S. Marines to evacuate Americans from war-torn Liberia and protect the U.S. Embassy there. He said he did not think any Americans were in ``imminent danger'' in Kuwait. In a thinly-veiled signal to Saddam, Fitzwater said the Liberia operation demonstrates that Bush ``is extremely concerned about the welfare of American citizens. We have acted time and again in behalf of their safety ... I'm sure that Iraq and other countries are aware of that.'' Bush spoke earlier Sunday with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and praised Japan's decision to ban oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, which have supplied more than 11 percent of Japan's oil. ``I appplaud Japan's stance, cracking down on the imports from Iraq,'' said Bush. The White House dismissed claims that Saddam was pulling his troops out of Kuwait three days after an invasion that replaced the 250-year-old monarchy with a new government supposedly composed of nine Kuwaiti army officers. ``We have no independent or confirmable information on this report,'' Fitzwater said. ``Saddam Hussein's actions in the past raise serious skepticism about his intentions.'' Boren, D-Okla., said on ABC-TV that intelligence reports did not indicate any troop rollback, particularly along the southern border with Saudi Arabia. ``So if they are taking anybody out, it's probably just a few people for show,'' he said. A U.S. official, who declined to be identified, said it appeared Iraqi troops were digging in rather than pulling out, building fortifications in some parts of the conquered country. As tensions rose in the region, the Washington Post reported Sunday that special operations forces and hostage rescue forces have been dispatched to the Mideast and that contingency plans call for sending Stealth fighters and B-52 bombers. ``I can't comment on any specific military actions or movements,'' Fitzwater said. However, he said the United States ``has extreme concern about the welfare of our citizens.'' Asked if the United States had asked Saudi Arabia for access to military facilities or landing rights to stage a military operation, Fitzwater said, ``We do not have any U.S. military staged in Saudi Arabia and we are discussing all options with them.'' The Saudis have been reluctant in the past to allow any U.S. military exercises on their soil, not wishing to provoke their neighbors. A senior administration official said there have been numerous cross-border sorties by the Iraqis into Saudi Arabian territory, but that they have been very small and very brief incursions. Fitzwater confirmed that 11 American oil workers rounded up in Kuwait after the invasion had been brought to Baghdad. He said they had talked with U.S. embassy officials and appeared to be in good shape. ``This accounts for all missing Americans,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Republics Moving Toward Greater Autonomy From Kremlin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Estonia, meanwhile ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with economic meeting Sunday in Estonia; picks up 13th graf, `Estonian Prime ...'
DOC.TEXT: Their independence declarations may be technically on hold, but the three Baltic republics continue to whittle away at the ties that bind them to the Kremlin. In the past week, Lithuania and Estonia have begun work on draft trade treaties with the Soviet Union's largest republic, bypassing the national government. Estonia may recruit its own police force to replace the Soviet militia. Latvia plans to start privatizing its economy by Oct. 1, regardless of what the rest of the country does. And all three republics have said they will not take part in negotiations to revise the treaty which binds the Soviet Union's 15 diverse republics together. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, meanwhile, meets regularly with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov to work out details for negotiations on Lithuanian independence. Steadily, the Baltic leaders have been taking matters into their own hands. They have been aided by the president of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, who seized the initiative on economic reform and pushed Gorbachev into accepting his ``500 Days'' program for the entire country. The Russian Federation is by far the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics and is home to more than half of the nation's population. While Gorbachev vacationed in the Crimea, Yeltsin took his holiday on the Baltic Sea in Latvia. He did not spend much time on the beach, news reports indicate. Instead, he met with Baltic leaders and offered to negotiate republic-to-republic treaties on political, economic, cultural, and other issues, bypassing the national government. Already, Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev and Mrs. Prunskiene have agreed on ``all the key issues that interest our republics'' and have asked their officials to prepare a draft economic treaty for as early as mid-August, the official Tass news agency reported. Eduardas Vilkas, a member of the Lithuanian negotiating commission, says the economic treaties envisage ``a free common market.'' Mrs. Prunskiene was quoted Saturday as telling the Interfax news service of Radio Moscow that some hitches remain, such as whether the Russian republic can guarantee to sell oil to Lithuania when the national government claims ownership of the energy industry. On Sunday, representatives of Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Byelorussia, Moldavia, the Russian Federation, the cities of Moscow and Leningrad, and the district of Leningrad met in the Estonian capital of Tallinn to begin ``economic cooperation based on treaties as a first step toward the ideas of a common market,'' the Estonian News Agency reported. The meeting was convened by the Estonian leadership to counter what the news agency called ``economic pressure from central authorities in Moscow.'' Estonia last week won an unpredecented concession from the national government when Soviet Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin agreed to give up his control of the republic's Interior Ministry and let Estonia create its own police force. Estonian Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar told the Izvestia newspaper that ``the Estonian government is now fully responsible before the population for ensuring public order, protection of citizens' rights and freedoms on the republic's territory.'' Latvian Prime Minister Ivar Godmanis, who recently returned from the United States, said economic experts from the Indianapolis-based Hudson Institute have agreed to come advise his government, and Latvian students will be sent to American business schools. ``Latvian private sector and not only farmers need the investments. If we are to overcome the present crisis, we should embark on privatization of the Latvian economy by Oct. 1 at the latest,'' he told the Postfactum news agency. Latvia plans to privatize 25-30 percent of the republic's economy, excluding land and natural resources, within four or five years. Property will be sold to private individuals or collectives, including foreign ones, or handed over to public and religious organizations. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, and Latvia and Estonia both have declared their intention to follow at the end of unspecified transition periods.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Fest Presents Jackie McLean's Music
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned
DOC.TEXT: Instead of waiting till the musician was 80, or gone, Lincoln Center's Classical Jazz series has devoted an evening to ``The Music of Jackie McLean,'' the 59-year-old alto saxophonist and teacher. The second of five Classical Jazz programs was held Saturday night before an enthusiastic, mostly young audience which packed Alice Tully Hall. McLean dedicated the evening to Walter Davis Jr., the pianist who was in Miles Davis' band when McLean joined it in 1951. McLean finished composing ``Walter Davis Ascending,'' on June 2, the day Davis died at age 57. Allen Palmer, Walter Davis' last pupil, was pianist for the upbeat piece. Music in the first half of the program was roiling, with drums, bass and piano all playing full out, each sounding as though the other two were in accompaniment. Other musicians came in and out, to make quintets and sextets. They included trumpeters Wynton Marsalis and Wallace Roney, tenor saxophonist Benny Golson, trombonist Curtis Fuller, pianist Larry Willis and drummer Arthur Taylor. The core group was pianist Hotep Idris Galeta, bassist Nat Reeves, drummer Carl Allen and McLean. The performance began with excitement and kept up throughout. The style was bebop to free, with melody. The free part also sounded purposeful, swinging and thought out. Pieces included ``Minor March,'' which Miles Davis recorded twice, and ``Little Melonae,'' which John Coltrane recorded. In the second half, musicians played as a nine-piece band, which offered greater variety. ``Appointment in Ghana'' had strong pulse and forward motion with the tune. ``Medley for Dolly,'' McLean's wife, included a broad melody and slow swinging into a romantic mood.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian President Appeals to Political Parties
DOC.TEXT: President Zhelyu Zhelev said Sunday that he will call immediate meetings with the country's political parties to try to find solutions for Bulgaria's social turmoil. In another development, anti-government protesters in the self-proclaimed ``City of Truth,'' who helped bring about the resignation last month of Zhelev's Socialist predecessor, began dismantling their tent city in downtown Sofia. It was not immediately clear how many of the estimated 300 people living there full-time would leave the pro-democracy encampment. Only a few of the tents, which at one point numbered about 170, were expected to remain. Zhelev said he would immediately call meetings with parties represented in Parliament ``to find a way out of the crisis,'' according to the state BTA news agency. In his televised speech, Bulgaria's first non-Communist president in 40 years also urged the parties to form a council to consult with him. He called on fellow opposition members to help him find an answer to Bulgaria's ``economic, political and moral crisis.'' Zhelev, a philosopher who led the opposition Union of Democratic Forces in June's free elections, was elected Wednesday by Parliament. Zhelev's election ended the parliamentary stalemate between Socialists and the opposition over a replacement for Petar Mladenov. Mladenov, a Socialist, resigned July 6 after he was accused of calling for tanks against anti-government demonstrations last year and amid threats of escalating strikes. The demonstrations started Bulgaria on a path of democratic reform. In November, Communist Party members ousted longtime leader Todor Zhivkov. They later changed the party's name to the Socialist Party. Zhelev says he favors the formation of a government of experts supported by both the Socialists and the Union of Democratic Forces. His statement indicated that some opposition members could join the government while avoiding a formal coalition. The opposition repeatedly has rejected offers of a coalition from incumbent Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov, arguing that the former Communist party must shoulder responsibility for past political crimes and the rapidly deteriorating economy. Zhelev also said Sunday that he would rescind all laws which violate the Constitution, ``in the first place those which infringe upon the fundamental rights of the citizens.'' He said he will soon lift restrictions on Bulgarians to move freely around the country, including the right to live in the capital. Earlier Sunday, the protesters made clear that they decided to remove their tents because their main demands have already been met by the government. That included a request that Zhivkov be allowed to speak before Parliament about his 35 years in power. Anti-government campers in other towns where tents have been pitched to campaign for greater democracy and other causes said they would continue their protest. The protesters, who have put up 13 tent cities in towns across Bulgaria, have claimed 250,000 supporters.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Mountain Accidents
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people were killed in a series of mountain accidents in the Alps on Sunday, rescue services and a news agency reported. Swiss air mountain rescue services said five German climbers who were roped together fell to their deaths while nearing the top of 11,117-foot Mt. Fruendenhorn. The climbers were not identified. On the Italian side of Mount Blanc, a shower of rocks struck two Japanese climbers, causing them to fall 1,600 feet to their deaths, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. It said the two were tied together as they were attempting to cross from one mountain shelter to another on the Alpine peak, which straddles Italy and France. ANSA identified the victims as Une Toshiaki, 43, an Alpine guide, and Wada Kayoka. It said Kayoka's age was not immediately available. The news agency said the two climbers had set out from Chamonix, in France, with a friend and a French guide. It said Kayoka's husband was killed two years ago in the same area during a climb. A Civil Defense helicopter recovered the bodies. The other two climbers were rescued unharmed, ANSA said. In other accidents, two Czechoslovak climbers were killed by a rockfall in Bergell in the canton of Grisons, and two others were injured, rescue services said. They also said an Austrian tourist fell to his death while climbing in the Engadine Alps, and a Swiss climber was also killed in another accident. Their identities were not released.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Steal $260,000 from Concert
DOC.TEXT: Three robbers with guns and a fake hand grenade stole $260,000 in proceeds Sunday after a concert by New Kids on the Block, police said. Police spokesman Jacques Morrisseau said the robbers, who were armed with revolvers, entered a room in Olympic Stadium where 12 employees were counting money from souvenir sales. New Kids on the Block, the teen pop sensation, had earlier played before a crowd of 57,000 at the stadium. The groups usually generates tens of thousands of dollars in sales of programs, caps and T-shirts before their concerts. The robbers handcuffed the employees and placed the fake hand grenade near a door. They told the terrified employees the grenade would explode if they tried to open the door. The robbers then made off with $260,000 in cash from the souvenir sales. The police bomb squad led the workers out of a rear door half an hour after the robbery. Police later discovered the grenade did not contain explosives.

DOC.HEAD: Rain From Southwest To Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain extended from New Mexico to New England on Sunday, with locally heavy rain flooding some streets and underpasses in Texas. Showers and thunderstorms extended over eastern Colorado, across the Nebraska Panhandle and southwestern Nebraska, western Kansas and the Oklahoma Panhandle into the northern Texas Panhandle. Showers and thunderstorms also reached from southeastern New Mexico and southwestern Texas across north-central Texas and across northern Louisiana, southern Alabama and the Florida Panhandle. Texas got the worst of the rain, with 2 inches at Fort Worth between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. and 2{ inches during the morning over parts of Comanche County in northern Texas. Water was up to 4 feet deep over some low-lying streets in northern Fort Worth, the National Weather Service said. Southwestern Texas also got heavy rain. Several highways near Eldorado were closed by high water and many low-water crossings were impassable, the weather service reported. Several small rivers in eastern Iowa were at or over flood stage. The Wapsipinicon River was near its crest at Dewitt and less than a foot above flood stage. The Skunk River was receding below below flood stage at Brighton; the Cedar was almost 3 feet over flood stage at Conesville but receding; the Kickapoo was cresting about a foot over flood stage at Gays Mills, the weather service said. Showers and storms also reached from northern Mississippi across Tennessee, Kentucky, West Virginia, southern and eastern Ohio, western Virginia, Pennsylvania, Maryland, New Jersey and New York state into western New England. Binghamton, N.Y., got an inch of rain in the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT. Elsewhere, showers and storms were scattered over southeastern Florida, central South Carolina, northeastern North Carolina and northeastern Illinois. Jacksonville, Fla., cooled to 69 degrees during the morning, tying the city's low temperature record for the date. Sunday's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 38 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 54 at Akron, Colo., to 106 at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Proposes Magna Carta For All Europeans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Thatcher's remarks on Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `We don't...
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Sunday called for a new Magna Carta that would establish basic rights for all Europeans, including the Soviets. Mrs. Thatcher also renewed her call for the United Nations to apply a total economic embargo against Iraq unless it withdraws without delay from its occupation of Kuwait. She said the embargo only would be fully effective if it were supported by all members of the United Nations. ``Iraq's invastion of Kuwait defies every principle for which the UN stands. If we let it succeed, no small country can ever feel safe again. The law of the jungle takes over,'' she said. The prime minister devoted most of her remarks to more than 3,000 people at the Aspen Institute to her vision of the new Europe. ``The European Community has reconciled antagonisms within Western Europe; it should now help to overcome divisions between East and West in Europe,'' she sand at the closing session of the Institute's 40th anniversary. ``We don't see this new Soviet Union as an enemy, but as a country groping its way towards freedom. We no longer have to view the world through the prism of East-West relations. The Cold War is over.'' At the end of her half-hour speech inside the big blue-and-white Aspen Music Festival tent, the crowd gave Thatcher a standing ovation. About 1,700 people were seated inside the big top. The rest were scattered about the lawn outside in the warm, summer air. Thatcher traveled to the institute to address its annual symposium and receive its Statesman Award, which recognized the prime minister's long reign and her commitment to democracy and peace. Thatcher met with President Bush in Aspen on Thursday before his opening address at the institute. She is scheduled to travel to Washington, D.C., Monday for an afternoon meeting with Bush, then return to London early Tuesday. During her speech, Thatcher said Western nations need to help nations struggling to establish democracy, but at the same time maintain a secure defense, including NATO and U.S. forces in Europe. ``The unity and strength which we in the West have found from joining together in defense can now be turned to serve more positive and ambitious purposes,'' she said. King John of England was forced by English barons to grant the original Magna Carta at Runnymede, England, June 15, 1215. It traditionally has been interpreted as guaranteeing certain civil and political liberties. The prime minister said her proposed European Magna Carta would ``entrench for every European citizen, including those of the Soviet Union, the basic rights we in the West take for granted.'' Among those rights: freedom of speech, worship, access to law and the marketplace, and the freedom to hold democratic elections, own property, maintain nationhood and remain free of ``fear of an over-mighty state.'' She also suggested that the European Community be poised to accept all Eastern European nations as members ``when democracy has taken root and their economies are capable of sustaining membership.'' ``We can't say in one breath that they are part of Europe, and in the next our European Community Club is so exclusive that we won't admit them,'' she said. Founded in 1950, the non-profit Aspen Institute gathers leaders in all parts of society to discuss critical issues of the world. The symposium this weekend concentrated on topics including health care and education.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Withdrawal Under Way; U.S. Disputes Claim
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 20th `The White...' to ADD U.N. sanctions expected, SUBS two grafs for 33-34 bgng `The Iraqi...' to RESTORE first reference to Saddam; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DXB1,3,NY22,27,WX7
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said it had started withdrawing part of its invasion force from Kuwait on Sunday, and the Kuwaiti government installed by Baghdad threatened to retaliate against any nation that challenges its legitimacy. In Washington, President Bush said Iraq had ``lied once again'' in claiming that it was withdrawing its invasion force. The president said he wanted to see Arab countries join in condemning the Iraqi invasion. Dozens of tanks, armored personnel carriers and trucks carrying hundreds of soldiers were seen crossing the border back into Iraq at the Safwan checkpoint, about 30 miles south of the Iraqi port city of Basra. However, thousands of Iraqi soldiers remained behind, tightening their grip on the oil-rich desert country. At his impromptu news conference, Bush said the United States would not recognize the Kuwaiti ``puppet government'' set up by Iraq. He refused to discuss any military action the United States might be planning, and he said his goal was to isolate Iraq internationally. U.S. officials said there was no indication Iraqi troops in southern Kuwait were preparing to invade Saudi Arabia. But Bush dispatched Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to Saudi Arabia to confer with leaders of the desert kingdom, administration sources said Sunday. Diplomats in the Persian Gulf, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that up to 80,000 soldiers of the new, largely Iraqi-staffed ``popular army'' of the provisional Kuwaiti government were fanning out across Kuwait. The television of the Iraqi-installed government in Kuwait, monitored in Bahrain, showed 30 minutes of continuous footage with military vehicles rolling back into Iraq, starting at 8 a.m. Twelve Arab reporters based in Baghdad were taken into Kuwait on Sunday by Iraq's Ministry of Information to observe the first Iraqi troops returning home. A senior Iraqi officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, ``The first phase of pulling out the Iraqi troops from the dusty desert state began, and we will continue as long as the security of the troops and situation in Kuwait allows.'' He refused to give details on how many Iraqi troops remained in Kuwait, saying there ``are enough to defend the sisterly Arab countries against any foreign aggression.'' About 100,000 Iraqi troops were estimated to have taken part in the initial invasion. The reporters could not locate any of the nine members of the new Kuwaiti provisional military government nor anyone who spoke for them. Roads connecting the Iraqi border with Kuwait city, about 60 miles away, were littered with cars hastily abandoned during the first hours of the invasion. Many had been smashed by tanks to clear a path. In Kuwait city, at least 30 burned and destroyed vehicles remained outside the defense ministry, where eyewitnesses said a battle raged for hours after Thursday's invasion. Hospital officials said many soldiers from both sides were killed during the first day of the invasion. They were unable to give exact figures, but said at least 300 died. Residents said the city was quiet during the daytime, but gunfire could be heard at night. Most residents remained behind closed doors, but some people ventured into the streets to search for food and stared at the Iraqi troops. In other developments Sunday: _Japan banned all oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and halted Japanese exports to both countries. Tokyo said it would suspend all loans to Iraq and Kuwait, ban Japanese investment there, and freeze Iraqi assets in Japan. Japan, which imports 99 percent of its oil, had relied on Iraq and Kuwait for more than 11 percent of its oil imports. The White House praised Japan for joining the many other nations that have already penalized Iraq for its invasion by imposing economic sanctions. _In New York, the United States urged other U.N. members at talks to impose broad economic and military sanctions on Iraq. Western diplomats said the world body is expected to adopt the measures Monday. _The emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, made his first public statements since fleeing to Saudi Arabia on Thursday. In a speech broadcast on Bahrain and Saudi television, the emir pledged that Kuwait would restore its territorial integrity, independence and sovereignty. He said, ``What makes our hearts filled with sadness is that the source of this unjustified agression was not an enemy, but a brother and a close neighbor. ...'' _Arab nations remained divided over how to react to the Iraqi invasion, and there was no indication that Saudi Arabia and Turkey were prepared to close the pipelines in their countries that carry the oil exported by Iraq. In Ankara, the Turkish capital, Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan warned that shutting down the pipeline ``would create mistrust'' between Iraq and Turkey. Prime Minister Mudar Badran of Jordan, a U.S. and Iraqi ally, said Sunday his nation would not recognize the provisional government in Kuwait because that would hinder Arab efforts to settle the crisis through negotiation. In Syria, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati met with President Hafez Assad to discuss ways of ensuring an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, according to official reports. Syria was Persian Iran's main Arab backer during its 1980-88 war with Iraq. _The White House said 11 American oil workers rounded up after the invasion had been brought to Baghdad, had talked with U.S. Embassy officials, and were in good shape. It said that accounts for all missing Americans. Britain said that 35 servicemen taken from their homes in Kuwait Saturday were being held in a Baghdad hotel and not allowed to leave the country. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday in a dispute over oil and territory, quickly deposed the monarchy, and seized control of Kuwait's vast oil reserves. The official Iraqi News Agency said the U.N. Security Council had been notified of the pullout, which it said was in line with an agreement between Baghdad and Kuwait's provisional government. The provisional government, in a statement carried by the Iraqi News Agency, told other countries to refrain from taking ``punishing measures'' against it or Iraq. The government said these countries ``have to remember they have interests and citizens in Kuwait'' and said it was prepared to close embassies and cut diplomatic relations with offending nations. The United States, which remains concerned about the 3,000 Americans still living in Kuwait, has already banned oil imports from Kuwait and Iraq and frozen both countries' assets in the United States. Baghdad TV has said the new Kuwaiti provisional government is headed by Col. Ala Hussein Ali. The other eight members were lieutenant colonels and majors. But Kuwait's embassy in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday called the new government as ``a list of fake names'' and said Ali is Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's son-in-law. The Kuwaiti Embassy in Tunis said Ali works for the Saddam administration. The Iraqi News Agency carried a Kuwait-datelined statement it said was issued by the provisional government, denying that any of its members were Iraqis.
