DOC.HEAD: United State Pushes for Iraqi Sanctions at United Nations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with U.S. ambassador's comments, comments from Britain, Cuba; DELETES outdated material thruout; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: UNITED NATIONS _ The United States urged other U.N. members at talks Sunday to impose broad economic and military sanctions on Iraq. Western diplomats said the world body is expected to adopt the measures. Should the U.N. Security Council impose comprehensive sanctions, it would be the first time since 1967 it has taken such action against a member state. The last time such sanctions were imposed was against the white minority government of Rhodesia. Western diplomats said they expected up to 14 positive votes on the 15-member council for sanctions against Iraq. They said they expected no vetoes, allowing the legally binding measure to be adopted, probably on Monday. They said Cuba was the holdout. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told reporters after closed-door talks Sunday that the council discussed ``the absolute necessity of moving ahead toward a broad resolution of sanctions.'' He said he expected a vote Monday. Pickering said the United States had circulated six or seven drafts of a detailed resolution. It calls for an embargo on Iraq's oil exports, an embargo on imports to Iraq, and a halt to all arms and other military supplies for Iraq. British Ambassador Crispen Tickell told reporters later that he detected ``strong support, with the exception of one member, for action and a vote tomorrow.'' Speaking of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Canadian Ambassador L. Yves Fortier declared, ``This madman must be stopped.'' Cuban envoy Ricardo Alarcon said Cuba would vote for sanctions against Iraq only if the council imposed sanctions on South Africa for occupying Namibia, Israel for occupying Palestinian territories and the United States for invading Panama. In Kuwait, the Iraqi-installed provisional government, in a statement carried by the Iraqi News Agency, told other countries to refrain from taking ``punishing measures'' against it or Iraq. The provisional government said countries ``have to remember they have interests and citizens in Kuwait.'' Kuwait's U.N. Ambassador Mohammad Abulhasan told reporters that the Iraqi-installed government was employing ``pure blackmail'' by saying it could not ensure the safety of foreigners if their governments support sanctions. In Aspen, Colo., British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher renewed her call for the United Nations to apply a total economic embargo against Iraq unless it withdraws immediately from Kuwait. ``Iraq's invasion of Kuwait defies every principle for which the U.N. stands. If we let it succeed, no small country can ever feel safe again. The law of the jungle takes over,'' she said, in remarks at the Aspen Institute. The U.N. role in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis assumed increasing importance after divided Arab nations cancelled an emergency summit on the invasion. On Thursday, the Security Council condemned Iraq's invasion, demanded immediate and unconditional troop withdrawal, and threatened to impose sanctions if Iraq did not pull out. Sunday's session was scheduled after weekend meetings of the council's five permanent members _ the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France _ and between the United States and representatives of the Non-Aligned Movement. They are the nations with the power to veto proposals. The United States contends that stiff sanctions by a united international front are necessary to punish Iraq and to force it to withdraw from Kuwait, which was invaded Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Second Power Outage In A Week Hits Chicago's West Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, 5th graf, to UPDATE with power restored. DELETES outdated reference to repairs. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `About 25,000...; SUBS 11th graf, `Mayor Richard ..' to conform
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire Sunday at an electrical substation caused the second power outage in a week on the city's West Side, cutting off electricity temporarily to about 25,000 customers, officials said. The fire was reported just after 9 a.m. at a substation that Commonwealth Edison had used to supply electricity to customers hit by last weekend's outage, an Edison spokeswoman said. The previous outage lasted up to two days and led to sporadic looting in the West Side, which contains some of the city's poorest neighborhoods. ``It was a powerful and serious explosion,'' Edison spokesman Steve Solomon said of Sunday's blast. An Edison operator at the site heard a transformer ``trip,'' or shut off because of a malfunction, then an explosion. He ran outside and saw the fire, said company spokeswoman Margaret Winters. The cause of the fire is under investigation. Winters at first said sabotage was possible, but later said it was unlikely. Power was restored to all customers by 4:35 p.m., Solomon said. About 25,000 customers in a 30-block-square area were affected, plus some customers on the eastern edge of the suburb of Oak Park, Winters said. Manny Patel, manager of a Baskin Robbins 31 Ice Cream Store in the affected area, said he lost about $4,000 worth of ice cream last week and would lose twice that amount this week if the power wasn't quickly restored. ``Last week I can understand _ things happen,'' he said. ``But two weeks in a row, I can't understand. Is this going to be a weekly thing?'' Temperatures were in the mid-70s, as they were during the July 28 outage, giving a break to residents whose fans and air conditioners were left powerless. The earlier outage, which came at 10 p.m. Saturday, was caused by a fire in a malfunctioning generator. It affected about 40,000 customers, including businesses that lost tens of thousands of dollars in perishables. The utility couldn't restore electricity to all affected customers until Tuesday. Mayor Richard M. Daley and other city officials toured the blacked-out area Sunday, and a Daley spokesman said the city had launched several initiatives to help residents cope. The Streets and Sanitation Department put up stop signs where street lights were out, said spokesman Terry Levin. ``We also have food inspectors out there to make sure that no spoiled food gets sold,'' he said. ``We have also been in contact with all the nursing homes in the area to make sure that there's no problem with electricity.''

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Forest Fire Destroys 28 Houses; Thousands Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to delete `Along the highway' reference, SUBS final graf pvs, `Elsewhere, fire..., with 6 grafs to ADD description, quotes; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BND2
DOC.TEXT: A fire driven by high winds and temperatures close to 100 degrees engulfed about 2,800 acres of parched forest, jumped a 75-foot-wide river canyon and destroyed 28 houses by Sunday afternoon. More than 2,800 people were evacuated Saturday night and Sunday from at least four motels or resorts and about 2,000 homes in six subdivisions south and west of Bend. The so-called Awbrey Hall fire erupted about 3 p.m. Saturday on a ridge six miles southwest of Bend, a city of about 19,000 on the eastern slopes of the Cascade Range in central Oregon. It quickly raced from treetop to treetop and jumped the Deschutes River. Kurt Larson said his family was driving home from a county fair late Saturday when they heard on the radio their subdivision had been evacuated. They rushed to their house and grabbed a few possessions. Larson, 45, a millworker, returned to the deserted neighborhood at 5:30 a.m. to check on his house, which was unscathed. ``I felt like the last man on earth,'' he said. ``It was really eerie.'' On Sunday, the northern boundary of the five-mile-long blaze was about a mile away from Central Oregon Community College in Bend. On the south, it was a mile away from the 325-room Inn at the Seventh Mountain. State and federal fire crews were able to construct a fire line around all but 3 miles of the blaze's circumference by Sunday afternoon. The temperature at 4 p.m. in Redmond, near Bend, was 97 degrees, with winds up to 13 mph. ``We have 2,800 acres burning actively this morning, and there are spotting problems already,'' said Forestry Department spokesman Doug Decker. Spotting occurs when embers are carried through the air ahead of the fire. Lynn Anderson of the interagency fire information center in Bend said most of the problems were on the northeastern corner of the fire, the one closest to town. About 100 miles south of Bend, a second fast-moving fire forced the evacuation of a subdivision and the 750 inhabitants of the town of Chiloquin were placed on alert, Decker said. He said that blaze had burned a structure, but he didn't know what it was. The cause of the Bend fire was under investigation but ``initial information indicates that it is not arson,'' said Linda Talifson of the fire information center. About 1,000 firefighters were working the fire with 65 fire engines, 14 bulldozers, six helicopters and six air tankers. The cost of fighting the fire in its first 15 hours was $646,000, Decker said. Smoke permeated Bend and was evident as far as Madras, 30 miles to the north. Dave Morman, also of the fire information center, said the fire had destroyed 28 homes. ``The ones I saw were pretty nice homes,'' he said. Damage was estimated at more than $4.5 million, said Decker. Gov. Neil Goldschmidt declared Deschutes County a disaster area late Saturday. The Red Cross set up emergency centers for the fire evacuees at two schools. At Bend Senior High School, volunteers arrived in a steady stream with bags of donated goods such as groceries, disposable diapers, bedding and pet food. ``A small community is very, very great for things like that,'' said the shelter manager, Lois Gumbert, 61, of Klamath Falls. Driven from their home, Larson and his wife, Jeanne, decided to volunteer at the shelter, where firefighters were fed before heading into the field and worried homeowners waited for updated damage reports. ``We couldn't sleep so we ended up coming down here and helping the Red Cross set tables for the firefighters,'' Mrs. Larson said. Employees of a local furniture and appliance store wheeled a big-screen television into the cafeteria at Bend High. One woman brought in a plate of brownies. Mrs. Larson said she only had time to gather a few household belongings, especially irreplaceable items like family photo albums. Waiting bred worry about the home they left behind to the whims of the advancing flames. ``You could see the ball of fire,'' she said. ``We're hoping that our house will still be there, but we don't know.'' Elsewhere, fire bosses in Utah plotted a new assault Sunday on a fire that has charred more than 5,000 acres in rugged country on the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation near Fort Duchesne.

DOC.HEAD: Man Says His Father Helped Assassinate John F. Kennedy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with FBI declining to comment, notes that conspiracy theories rife since Kennedy's death; CORRECTS spelling in 3rd graf back to Connally sted Connally; picks up 5th graf pvs, White said...
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed oil equipment salesman claims that his late father, a former Dallas police officer, was one of three men who assassinated President John F. Kennedy in 1963. Ricky White scheduled a meeting with reporters Monday in Dallas to offer evidence he said implicates his father, Roscoe White, in the assassination, the Austin American-Statesman reported Sunday. The Warren Commission concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald, acting alone, fired the shots that killed Kennedy and wounded Texas Gov. John Connally. Despite the commission's findings, conspiracy theories have abounded over 27 years. White, 29, said he ``had no conception of ever, ever giving this story out,'' but decided to do so after the FBI began questioning him in May 1988 in relation to his claims. Woody Specht, FBI special agent in Dallas, refused to comment on the claims, other than to say: ``You really need to evaluate the source on these types of things.'' White said he can prove that his father fired two of the three bullets that killed the president and that his father, not Oswald, also killed Dallas police officer J.D. Tippit less than an hour after the assassination. White said Oswald was involved in the plot, but did not fire any shots. The two other shooters were referred to in his father's diary only by code names, White said. Roscoe White died in a fire in 1971. The evidence White reportedly will provide includes a rifle with telescopic sight that uses ammunition he said is similar to that used in Oswald's gun; records showing Oswald and White served together in the Marines; and three faded messages he believes were sent by U.S. intelligence officials ordering Kennedy's assassination in Dallas in November 1963. Bobby Inman, the former deputy CIA director, viewed the messages and told the American-Statesman they were not genuine. White, an unemployed equipment salesman in Midland, said that he and his mother read his father's diary, which detailed the assassination. His mother, Geneva White, is seriously ill and unable to be interviewed, family members told the newspaper. The diary disappeared from his home after it was inspected by the FBI, White says. White said his mother worked briefly at Jack Ruby's Carousel Club in Dallas. Ruby fatally shot Oswald two days after Kennedy was assassinated. Clues found among his father's effects and available government records show that Roscoe White and Oswald served together in the U.S. Marine Corps in the late 1950s, Ricky White said. He said his father claimed to have become acquainted with Oswald in Japan and the Philippines. He said his father's possessions also included a photograph, taken by Marina Oswald of her husband, Lee Harvey Oswald, holding a rifle in the back yard of their Dallas home in 1963. Oswald was discharged in 1959 and defected to the Soviet Union. He returned to the United States in 1962, settling first in Fort Worth before moving to Dallas. The elder White was discharged in late 1962 and joined his wife and two sons in Paris, Texas. Ricky White says his family later moved to Dallas where his father sold insurance. Dallas police records show that on Oct. 7, 1963, Roscoe White joined the department as a photographer and clerk, and that he became a patrol officer in 1964. White says his father shot from behind a fence atop the grassy knoll that was to the right and front of Kennedy's limousine when he was shot. He says the other two gunmen were behind the limousine in the Texas School Book Depository, where Oswald also was, and in a second building. As the incriminating evidence began to mount against his father, Ricky White asked the JFK Assassination Information Center in Dallas to verify or disprove his father's involvement, center director Larry Howard told The Associated Press. The information center is a private group that has pursued the idea of a conspiracy and coverup in Kennedy's death. ``He's actually very courageous to follow this thing through,'' Howard said Sunday. ``The amount of documentation we have to back his story up is just incredible.'' Howard said he has been working with White for 1{ years, and hopes White's story will lead to a new investigation of the assassination. ``I've never been so convinced of anything in my life,'' Howard said. ``We're not saying that we've solved the John F. Kennedy assassination case but this sure opens the doors to another investigation.'' Howard said Americans are fascinated by JFK's assassination. ``I think they know that it was a massive coverup in the very beginning and they want to know the truth,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Oil Export Routes Highly Vulnerable
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 6th to CORRECT current capacity at Mina al-Bakr to 800,000 sted 800,000 million; CLARIFY that capacity is daily; pickup graf 7 `But with...' ^With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq exports much of its oil through pipelines across Saudi Arabia and Turkey, with the rest shipped via the Persian Gulf. All three routes are highly vulnerable. The $2.7 billion twin pipeline through Saudi Arabia, which ends at the Red Sea oil terminal at al-Mu'ajjis, has a capacity of 1.65 million barrels a day. The 979-mile pipeline was a central element in Iraq's plan to seek alternative oil routes during the Iran-Iraq war, when Iranian raids on gulf shipping almost shut down sea routes. Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer has described the pipeline as a ``symbol of the deep ties between the two countries.'' Another pipeline with a capacity of 1.6 million barrels a day snakes through 612 miles of southeastern Turkey to the Mediterranean oil terminal at Ceyhan. Oil shipped through the gulf passes through Iraq's Mina al-Bakr terminal, which when post-war rebuilding work is completed, will have a design capacity to load 1.6 million barrels a day into tankers. Its current capacity is 800,000 barrels. But with the United States, Japan and the European Community announcing embargos on Iraqi oil after Iraq's invasion Thursday of Kuwait, the question is whether President Saddam Hussein will be able to sell it. In addition, the pipelines are highly vulnerable to military attack and their operation depends on the cooperation of Saudi Arabia and Turkey. So far, those two countries have given no indication of any willingness to interfere with the oil flow, with Saudi Arabia reportedly fearful that any such action could provide Baghdad with a pretext to send its army into the oil-rich kingdom. But the possibility remains. As for the gulf route, the Iran-Iraq war demonstrated vividly that it can be virtually shut down by military aircraft, missiles, gunboats and possibly a naval blockade. At times during the eight-year gulf war with Iran, Iraq's oil output fell below 1 million barrels a day but now it ranks again among the world's oil giants. Iraq itself has increased its production capacity to 4.5 million barrels a day, although it has kept its output no higher than its Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries quota of 3.14 million barrels a day. Kuwait's violation of its OPEC quota was one factor that pushed oil prices down, sparking Saddam's anger and costing Baghdad losses of $14 billion, Iraq said. Kuwait has an OPEC quota of 1.5 million barrels of oil a day but had been producing up to 1.9 million barrels a day, and it has capacity to produce even more. Iraq has more than 100 billion barrels of oil reserves, while tiny Kuwait itself floats on a sea of 94 billion barrels of oil. Both countries, however, still rely on foreign expertise both to extract the oil and to conduct exploration work. The Western sanctions will eliminate much of this assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Strict Air Force Standards Leave `Super Clinic' Without Surgeons
DOC.TEXT: A $16 million ``super clinic'' that opened at Malmstrom Air Force Base three months ago isn't getting full use because strict Air Force regulations disqualify most local doctors from working there. Airmen and their families are being treated at two local hospitals _ at greater expense _ by the same doctors. ``It's ironic,'' said Dr. Peter Horst, a private urologist. ``The Air Force is perfectly comfortable with us doing the same work at local hospitals that we can't do at the new base clinic.'' The clinic has been billed as the first non-hospital in the military designed for out-patient surgery that civilian hospitals offer. Twenty Great Falls physicians won contracts totaling about $600,000 to perform surgery at the new base clinic, in addition to their other work. But the Air Force has more stringent standards for physicians who conduct so-called major surgery, such as hernia repairs, than either Columbus Hospital or the Montana Deaconess Medical Center. Some of the surgeons tabbed to work at the Air Force clinic plan to upgrade their medical certification, but 12 anesthesiologists have balked at other Air Force requirements, like a dress code and mandatory AIDS test. Horst estimated the certification would require two to 10 hours of study and a few hours of testing. The problem was discovered in April, when paperwork was being signed. ``We assumed the standards for downtown providers are the same as for the Air Force, but they weren't,'' said Col. Ronald Burnett, clinic commander. The service standards are more rigorous than at other Montana hospitals and by the commission that accredits most civilian hospitals, said Dr. John Highsmith, chief of clinical services at Malmstrom. The reason for the Air Force standards is not clear, but the Air Force has refused to grant Malmstrom a waiver. A primary Air Force requirement is that all doctors working in high-risk fields to be certified in advanced cardiac life support. Only one of the 20 Great Falls doctors has such certification. ``They obviously have the skills but may need a refresher course,'' Highsmith said. ``It will be a formality to most of them _ but it's a required formality.'' Malmstrom offered a certification course in June, but most of the doctors could not rearrange their schedules on short notice. The Air Force is paying $1,500 to run another course Wednesday. Seven doctors had signed up last week. Anesthesiologists are required for major surgery, but the 12 local specialists decided against working at the clinic because of the dress code and AIDS test, and increased demand for their services at the city's hospitals, said Dr. Fred Fleming. Malmstrom may have to hire resident anesthesiologists, a process that could take months, Burnett said.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Whips Yucutan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with storm advancing, two towns hard-hit, 9 p.m. update from Hurricane Center; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Diana spun off the Caribbean and across the Yucatan Peninsula with 45 mph winds Sunday. No major damage or injuries were immediately reported. The U.S. National Hurricane Center said the storm had hit the coast by midafternoon about 70 miles northeast of Chetumal, capital of Quintana Roo state. At 9 p.m. EDT, Diana was centered about 70 miles southeast of Merida, Mexico. It carried maximum winds of 45 mph and was moving northwest at 15 mph, according to the center in Coral Gables, Fla. Earlier, civil defense officials in Quintana Roo state had issued a bulletin recommending that ``inhabitants of coastal zones evacuate areas which could be flooded and homes which could suffer damage due to weak construction.'' It said refugee centers had been set up in elementary schools in the towns of Xcalak, Punta Herrero and Punta Allen. People in the towns of Felipe Carrillo Puerto and Jose Maria Morelos were urged to secure their belongings and move to primary school shelters if their homes are not sturdy. State government spokesman Javier Venegas said those two towns were the hardest hit. Residents of Cozumel and nearby towns were also urged to secure their belongings and to be ready to move if necessary. The storm had crossed Quintana Roo by mid-evening and entered the state of Yucatan, heading northwest toward the Gulf of Mexico, said Venegas. However, heavy rain continued to fall, he said. Army crews said all federal roads in the state remained open. Other teams were checking for flooding. Officials said they expected the storm to bring high winds and heavy rains to the peninsula for up to 24 hours before heading on toward the Gulf of Mexico. U.S. Hurricane Center forecaster Bob Case said five to eight inches rain are possible along Diana's path across the Yucatan. The center of the storm was expected to emerge over the southern Gulf of Mexico by early Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Outcome of Case Hinges on Credibility of Dueling Experts
DOC.TEXT: A judge may be asked this week to decide whether a faint message was inserted into the blasting soundtrack of a heavy-metal rock album, and whether that message drove two troubled youths to try suicide. Attorneys for the families of Raymond Belknap and James Vance concede there is not overwhelming scientific evidence to support their claim that such subliminal words can be comprehended by a person's unconscious mind and cause dramatic consequences. The families' case against the British rock band Judas Priest and CBS Records is expected to conclude this week. Then, Washoe District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead will decide if the band's ``Stained Class'' album does contain hidden messages and, if so, whether they contributed to the youths' deaths. Belknap, 18, died on Dec. 23, 1985, after firing a sawed-off shotgun in his mouth. Vance, then 20, blew away the lower portion of his face; he underwent numerous reconstructive surgeries before dying on Thanksgiving Day 1988 of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medications. Neither side disputes that the youths drank beer, smoked marijuana and listened to the Judas Priest album before shooting themselves. And they don't disagree that the use of drugs and alcohol contributed to the young men's fates. There are few additional points of agreement. The defense maintains the youths' substance abuse, family violence, brushes with the law and personality disorders predestined their suicides. Attorneys for the families contend it was the Judas Priest album, specifically the alleged subliminal message ``do it'' on the song ``Better By You, Better Than Me,'' a song dealing with suicide, that pushed them over the edge. Ken McKenna and Vivian Lynch, representing the families, offered the testimony of a University of Michigan psychology professor to support their case. Howard Shevrin said that while the youths had a predisposition toward taking their lives, they would not have tried without the subliminal messages. He said such a message issued in the form of a command, such as ``do it,'' can create a compulsion that renders a person helpless to deny it. ``They had no choice,'' Ms. Lynch said. ``They were compelled to do what they did. It was totally beyond their control.'' But Shevrin's testimony relied on the opinion of another witness, William Nickloff, that the hidden messages exist, masked by the pounding music. Defense attorneys Suellen Fulstone and Bill Peterson challenged Nickloff's credibility, saying he held a degree in marine biology and lacked expertise to pass judgment on the music's content. The band denies subliminal messages exist on the album. Lead singer Rob Halford gave a 10-second courtroom concert, singing two lines from ``Better By You, Better Than Me,'' to exhibit his explosive breathing style. He said the alleged ``do it'' was no more than an exhalation combined with guitars and drums. Additional defense witnesses countered that the whole idea of auditory subliminal messages is nonsense because it is impossible to record below the frequency of ``white noise,'' a low hissing found on all recordings. Still others said the brain cannot perceive anything it can't hear. ``You hear what you hear,'' Stanford University Medical School psychiatrist Donald Lunde said. ``We don't have more than one mind up there. It either hears it, perceives it and registers it or it doesn't.'' The judge ruled the song lyrics are protected by the First Amendment and are not on trial, but allowed the plaintiffs to present testimony regarding themes found in heavy metal music. Ms. Lynch said the music's underlying themes focus on death, rebellion and suicide, and therefore are relevant because they enhance the predispositions of listeners, many of whom are teen-agers. McKenna said the plaintiffs won a small victory last week when Halford said under oath he used reversed lyrics on a song in a Judas Priest album recorded seven years after ``Stained Class.''

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices To Distributers Rise On Iraqi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline dealers paid 9.5 cents more per gallon last week for regular unleaded gasoline following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, a survey of suppliers said Sunday. The Lundberg Survey of wholesale prices, the amount gasoline dealers pay for their product, showed nationwide average prices checked Friday rose to 76.5 cents a gallon among the most price-sensitive wholesalers. The survey is taken weekly of about 75 percent to 80 percent of suppliers of refined gasoline in the United States. Figures gathered since Friday indicate a weekend of increases. Rough estimates show prices from the most price-sensitive suppliers have gone up another 6 cents, survey chief Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. Crude oil bought at last week's higher prices won't be refined and flowing from U.S. gasoline pumps for about a month. But Lundberg and an oil company spokesman said increases in the spot market for gasoline translate into higher pump prices more quickly during the summer. Many oil companies sell more gasoline than they refine during the heavy-driving summer months, so they have to supplement their supplies by buying on the volitile spot market, said John Lord, a spokesman for Mobil Oil Co. in New York. ``The refinery industry is cranking out every gallon of gasoline it can, and still has to buy on the spot market. The impact on the gasoline distributing system is faster than ever,'' Lundberg said. Lord also said many are apparently anticipating higher costs from the Iraq-Kuwait conflict. ``When you know future costs are going to go up, if you can recover some of those costs today, you're going to do it if the price will hold,'' Lord said. ``I think that's what's going on in the marketplace.'' Other increases over the week for the same grade of gasoline were 4.73 cents, for 74.5 cents a gallon, for middle-market distributors and 2.55 cents, for just over 78 cents a gallon, for the most stable part of the market. Since Friday, estimates show prices in the middle market have risen 3.25 cents, and 3.50 cents for the upper, or most stable, market, Lundberg said. The most price-sensitive are the independent wholesalers that have few, if any, long-term contracts with gasoline dealers, and meet demand by getting supplies on the spot market. The most stable are those who deliver branded gasoline to stations under a contract. Their higher base price allows more of a cushion before changes affect their costs.
